goals.strategies_summarized: To achieve the goal of 70% of multilingual learner students in grades 2-5 scoring in the Low or Minimal Risk range on the Spring 2028 FastBridge "aReading" Assessment, Alcott Elementary will implement a comprehensive, multi-faceted literacy approach grounded in foundational instruction and data-driven intervention. K-2 staff will utilize evidence-based curricula including Heggerty Phonemic Awareness and UFLI, while K-5 staff will explore Word Study and Seesaw as optional resources and engage with Lexia as a differentiation tool, with yearly usage reviews to ensure fidelity and effectiveness. Instruction will be supported through regularly monitored small group instruction, peer collaboration, and questioning strategies aligned with the Danielson Framework for Teaching, coupled with the use of MTSS tier 1 and tier 2 literacy interventions delivered through scheduled intervention blocks and informed by yearly WIDA Screener data reviews. Finally, staff will engage in ongoing professional learning communities to complete data cycles using FastBridge results and a structured Data Protocol, while participating in a minimum of three yearly collaboration meetings between classroom and multilingual services staff to ensure coordinated, responsive approaches to student learning needs.

goals.strategies_summarized: Alcott Elementary will implement a comprehensive, multi-layered approach to support multilingual learners in grades 2-5 by adopting the Illustrative Mathematics curriculum, establishing scheduled collaboration meetings between classroom and ML services staff at least three times yearly, and utilizing MTSS tier 1 and tier 2 instructional interventions alongside differentiated tools including DreamBox and Seesaw. Teachers will employ frequently monitored small group instruction, leverage intervention blocks within the school schedule, and use critical data matrices during MTSS and gifted and talented processes to respond flexibly to student needs. Professional learning communities will engage in ongoing data cycles using FastBridge results and a structured data protocol, while staff will be supported through professional development based on The Framework for Teaching Domain 3 to implement question/discussion/reflection strategies and peer collaboration opportunities that foster purposeful learning for all students.

goals.strategies_summarized: To achieve 85% favorable responses in Social Awareness on the 2028 Spring Panorama survey, Alcott Elementary will implement a comprehensive, school-wide approach centered on the "Alcott CAREs" PBIS program, complemented by targeted social-emotional learning curricula including Zones of Regulation and the Purposeful People "Be Kind" curriculum delivered through counselor classroom lessons and regular check-ins. Staff will reinforce positive social awareness behaviors through consistent praise and recognition tracked via "Orca Tails" data, while providing students with accessible calming zones and regular opportunities to practice empathy and self-regulation skills. Additionally, the school will foster an inclusive environment by celebrating student and family differences through Heritage Months and Recognition Weeks, supported by ongoing staff training in equity and inclusion to ensure all staff members effectively implement these strategies throughout the school year.

goals.focus_group: Focus grade levels are kindergarten and first grade to build strong early foundational skills of reading.
goals.outcome: Students will show growth in phonemic awareness and phonics and fluency, dependent on grade level and standard. Adults will collaborate to support students including general education, special education, multilingual learner, reading specialist and instructional assistant staff.
goals.currentdata: As a school we have focused on early literacy practices for the past few years. There has been a focus on small group instruction, training for teachers in UFLI and Heggerty curriculum, and alignment across student support teams to maximize learning. Last year’s SIP goal was to increase the percentage of students on track to meet grade level benchmarks by the end of the year, focusing on kindergarten and 1st grade. We showed success, particularly in first grade. According to Fall Fastbridge data, at least 85% of current second graders are on track to meet grade level benchmarks by the end of the year (up from 71% and 74% last year): 88% on track in phonemic awareness 85% on track in phonics and fluency Current 1st graders are: 77% on track in phonemic awareness 77% on track in phonics and fluency Current Kindergarten students are: 76% on track in phonemic awareness 88% on track in phonics and fluency This means we partially met the goal and will continue to focus on phonemic awareness and phonics & fluency with the goal that

goals.strategies_summarized: Audubon Elementary will implement a comprehensive, multi-faceted approach to support student growth in phonemic awareness, phonics, and fluency by creating a protected literacy block within the building schedule that includes core instruction and intervention time for all students, while simultaneously establishing a robust professional development program grounded in the Science of Reading and UFLI implementation for all staff members serving primary students. To ensure seamless collaboration across general education, special education, multilingual, and support staff, the school will increase structured PLC and team meeting time focused on aligning goals, content, and instructional practices, with particular attention to integrating multilingual strategies that address language barriers and maximize student access to grade-level content. Additionally, Audubon Elementary will implement UFLI in all primary classrooms supplemented by Heggerty and Wonders as needed, provide ongoing staff development in SIOP strategies, and intentionally preplan, teach, and review academic language across small and large group settings, with assignment modifications documented and shared to remove linguistic obstacles to learning.
goals.engagement_strategies: Curriculum presentations in the fall from each staff member including additional reading specialist literacy night and ML literacy night. Monthly meetings with PTSA presidents and active discussion around school improvement planning.

goals.focus_group: Multilingual Students, especially those who are in 3rd, 4th, and 5th grade and who are receiving supports from the ML program.
goals.focus_area: Developing academic language that allows all students to access math instruction.
goals.outcome: To close the achievement gap that exists in math between students served in ML and those who are either exited or never served.
goals.currentdata: The student population at Audubon shows that at least 50% of students are multi-lingual learners and have varying needs related to academic language development: 25% of students are multi-lingual and are actively receiving ML services. 25% previously received ML services and have exited the program. 50% have never qualified for ML services, but may speak multiple languages. Smarter Balanced Assessment scores from the 2024-2025 school year show the following percentages of students meeting standard in math: 59% of students eligible for ML services 90% of students previously eligible for ML services 85% of students never eligible for ML services This data along with teacher observation indicates a need for robust supports to help students develop academic language that will reduce the language barrier in math.

goals.strategies_summarized: To close the achievement gap in math between multilingual learners and exited or never-served students, Audubon Elementary will implement a comprehensive, coordinated approach. The school will create a protective schedule that prioritizes math core instruction while allowing for small group interventions and will coordinate ML services (push-in, pull-out, and collaborative support with reading specialists and special education) tailored to individual student needs. Additionally, staff will collaborate across grade levels and departments to align ML practices with math content, provide targeted instruction in mathematical language through varied strategies, participate in professional development focused on SIOP strategies, and modify assignments to remove language barriers while maintaining cognitive rigor.

goals.focus_group: All students at Audubon will feel a sense of belonging to the school through relationships with adults, other students, and the overall school community.
goals.outcome: All students will feel connected to the school, adults, and other students.
goals.currentdata: As a school we have focused on student sense of belonging for many School Improvement Plans, and both Panorama and building created measures continue to show a percentage of students who feel connected at 65-75%. The percentage has not shown a significant change since 2019. In previous years we have focused on schoolwide practices, teacher student relationships through classroom SEL supports, and student to student connections. This year we continue to look for ways to connect each and every student to the school community. This year we will recenter practices and collaborate more efficiently to increase student sense of belonging. We will reimagine SEL lessons with special education staff and the counselor collaborating closely with teachers for co-teaching, whole group, and small group lessons as needed.

goals.strategies_summarized: To help all students feel connected to the school, adults, and other students, Audubon Elementary will implement multiple initiatives including regular community circles in classrooms with supportive resources, increased social opportunities such as mixed-grade recess and flexible lunch arrangements, and counselor-led small group lessons designed to include cross-served students. The school will assess the effectiveness of these efforts through various measures including Panorama surveys, youth needs surveys, and staff-created assessments to ensure students develop a strong sense of belonging across all grade levels.

goals.strategies_summarized: A. G. Bell Elementary will implement a comprehensive, multi-layered literacy intervention approach targeting Black and Hispanic/Latino/LatinX students through small group differentiated instruction in phonemic awareness using curricular tools and Lexia, coupled with systematic phonics instruction via UFLI Foundations and Heggerty implemented daily in K-2 classrooms with consistent hand and verbal cues. The school will enhance instruction through SIOP strategies including visual aids, interactive games, and explicit modeling, while providing individualized multilingual support from ML teachers and employing culturally responsive teaching practices, all monitored through formal and informal observations and progress monitoring data. Additionally, the school will build collaborative systems across departments (ML, Special Education, interventionists), implement student engagement strategies using street data rubrics, and provide wireless hotspots and devices to ensure equitable access to Lexia and Lexia English for home use.

goals.focus_area: Solving problems involving the four operations and patterns.
goals.outcome: As measured by the Math SBA target 3D, overall student performance indicators will be averaged as “similar” or “better” relative to the test. Additionally, all students in K-5 will show realistic growth or more on the FastBridge Math assessment (aMath or earlymath).
goals.currentdata: SBA Math Claim 1 Concepts and Procedures states: Students can explain and apply mathematical concepts and carry out mathematical procedures with precision and fluency. Target D within this claim centers on problems involving the four operations, and students' ability to successfully identify and explain patterns in arithmetic. The two Common Core Math Standards linked to this target/claim are: • 3.OA.8: Solve two‐step word problems using the four operations. Represent these problems using equations with a letter standing for the unknown quantity. Assess the reasonableness of answers using mental computation and estimation strategies including rounding, • 3.OA.9: Identify arithmetic patterns and explain them using properties of operations. Bell students, as measured by the 2024 Spring administration of the Smarter Balanced Assessment (SBA) scored “worse” as relative to the entire test and “below” as relative the Level 3/at standard scores, on Claim 1 Target D:

goals.strategies_summarized: A. G. Bell Elementary will implement targeted small group instruction and centers focused on math patterns and operations, utilizing FastBridge, Dreambox, and teacher-created assessments to identify student needs and monitor progress through collaborative PLC meetings. The school will allocate dedicated daily time (30-50 minutes) for differentiated small group instruction and Illustrative Math Centers, supported by gamified learning experiences through tools like Kahoot and math manipulatives, while building-wide implementation of Dreambox during small group rotations provides consistent progress monitoring. Additionally, teachers will receive professional learning on structuring effective math small group time and will employ Instructional Playbook and SIOP strategies to increase student expression and participation, while the Student-Generated Street Data Rubric will track engagement through classroom observations and student surveys; home access will be expanded through wireless hotspots and devices to extend learning opportunities with Dreambox and Xtramath.

strategies.action: Self-Efficacy Integrated into Academic Curriculum through activities such as: • Growth mindset lessons focused on perseverance, effort, and learning from mistakes. • Self-Reflection Opportunities such as journal prompts. • Student Data Tracking to emphasize growth and progress. • Problem-Solving Activities throughout our math, science, reading, social studies, and writing curriculums.

goals.strategies_summarized: A. G. Bell Elementary will implement a comprehensive, multi-faceted approach to improve student self-efficacy by integrating growth mindset lessons, self-reflection activities, and problem-solving tasks throughout the academic curriculum while simultaneously providing social-emotional learning through Second Step lessons, monthly attribute assemblies focused on perseverance, daily morning meetings, and student leadership opportunities. The school will support these initiatives through teacher professional development on collective and student efficacy, student recognition programs, small-group counselor support for students needing additional assistance, and active student engagement in goal-setting and progress monitoring using data notebooks. Progress toward the outcome will be measured through administration of a building-created Self-Efficacy Survey and Panorama Survey Results, as well as through classroom observations documenting integration of self-efficacy activities, exit tickets from counselor-led lessons, participation rates in leadership programs and recognition activities, and the percentage of classrooms implementing data-tracking systems.
goals.engagement_strategies: January parent/student/teacher progress conferences with intentional focus on Self Efficacy and “yet” goals. Interest in Innovation Lab Site Opportunity to strengthen our family engagement tool kit Student Self-Efficacy Goal shared at first General PTSA membership meeting to promote collaboration on supporting students’ self-efficacy throughout the year. Student Panel invited to October LEAP Day to share student perspective on improving instruction and overall student experience. Continued professional learning and incorporation of student voice and choice in classrooms and building wide decision making, in partnership with JoySource consulting/coaching. Black/Hispanic/Latino/LatinX family/parent/community engagement and student experience survey, in home languages, implemented winter 2025.

goals.outcome: 88% of students in grades 3 – 5 will be at or above standard in ELA as measured by the Smarter Balanced Assessment in Spring of 2028 Write or revise one or more paragraphs demonstrating ability to stay on topics or use sources; organize ideas and develop supporting evidence/reasons and elaboration.
goals.currentdata: After examining Blackwell’s ELA target data beginning in spring 2022, we have found that performance in some target areas within writing and reading was lower for our students relative to other portions of the test. These target areas were consistent across grades 3, 4, and 5. Specifically, students scored relatively lower in the target area of “writing and revising brief texts.” Included within this target area is writing and revising one or more paragraphs, organizing ideas, and providing supporting evidence and elaboration. The data supports an increased focus on writing and reading instructional strategies at Blackwell. Targeted instruction will be provided across curriculum content areas of writing in mathematics, social studies, and science to lend themselves to naturally harvest writing opportunities for students. During the spring 2025 SBA assessment, relative lower cohort target achievements were noted in the target area of “writing and revising brief texts” and in Reading specifically when “making inferences.” The data supports an increase in focus on these areas in our instruction of these reading and writing areas.

goals.strategies_summarized: Elizabeth Blackwell Elementary School will achieve the 88% proficiency target in ELA for grades 3-5 by implementing a comprehensive, multi-faceted approach that strengthens writing and reading instruction across all grade levels. Teachers will ensure fidelity in using district-provided curricula while integrating writing across content areas and incorporating culturally responsive teaching strategies that connect to students' background knowledge. Additionally, the school will provide targeted, grade-level instruction—with grades K-2 focusing on topics and supporting details and grades 3-5 explicitly teaching organizational structure—supported by special education teachers' coordinated schedules during reading intervention blocks and regular analysis of student work against annotated samples and rubrics. The MTSS team will identify students needing additional support through FastBridge data, while grade-level teams will collaborate to identify critical lesson components that support organization and revision, and teachers will utilize SBA Interim Assessments and inquiry-based strategies to prepare students for success on the spring 2028 Smarter Balanced Assessment.

goals.focus_area: Math Target Areas: • Grade 3: Represent and solve problems involving multiplication and division. • Grade 4: Use place value understanding and properties of operations to perform multi-digit arithmetic. • Grade 5: Represent and interpret data
goals.outcome: 86% of students in grades 3 – 5 will be at or above standard in Mathematics as measured by the Smarter Balanced Assessment in Spring of 2028
goals.currentdata: After examining Blackwell’s Math target data, we have found grade levels were proficient in mathematics however, there are specific performances in some target areas within mathematics that were lower for our students relative to other portions of the test. The math target areas differed across grades 3, 4, and 5 in the 2023-24 school year were: • Grade 3: Represent and solve problems involving multiplication and division; Solve problems involving the four operations and identify and explain patterns in arithmetic; Represent and interpret data. • Grade 4: Use the four operations with whole numbers to solve problems; Generalize place value understanding for multi-digit whole numbers; Use place value understanding and properties of operations to perform multi-digit arithmetic; Solve problems involving measurement and conversion of measurements from a larger unit to a smaller unit; Draw and identify lines and angles and classify shapes by properties of their lines and angles. • Grade 5: Graph points on the coordinate plane to solve real-world and mathematical problems. The most recent SBA (spring, 2025) math results demonstrate that these target areas are no longer deemed relatively lower in the students’ proficiency. The math target areas noted on the spring 2025 SBA results showed relatively lower success in two target areas.

goals.strategies_summarized: To achieve 86% of students in grades 3–5 at or above standard in Mathematics on the Spring 2028 Smarter Balanced Assessment, Elizabeth Blackwell Elementary School will implement a comprehensive, multi-faceted approach centered on strengthened instructional practices and targeted student support. Teachers will utilize inquiry-based and problem-solving strategies from the adopted curriculum while participating in vertical teaming through LEAP to ensure consistent instruction across grade levels and adequate exposure to late-spring units before the assessment. Additionally, the school will deploy SBA Interim Assessments for test preparation, establish regular intervention block schedules supported by Special Education teachers, assign instructional assistants to grades 4 and 5, and leverage common problem-solving strategies (such as 3 Reads and Building Thinking Classrooms) alongside data from FastBridge to personalize learning through tools like Dreambox and Illustrative Math. All efforts will be supported through collaboration with an instructional coach, implementation of six-week data cycles, and integration of formative assessments to monitor progress and adjust instruction accordingly.

goals.strategies_summarized: To achieve 80% of students in grades 3–5 responding favorably to their Sense of Belonging on the Spring 2027 Panorama Survey, Elizabeth Blackwell Elementary School will implement a comprehensive, multi-faceted approach that centers on recognition, inclusion, and community building. The school will maintain and expand the Blackwell Belonging initiative through the CARES program, host family engagement events like Blackwell Belonging Night, and create extracurricular opportunities that allow all students to participate and feel valued. goals.strategies_summarized: To achieve 100% of students on track with CBM reading scores by the end of 2nd grade, Rachel Carson Elementary will implement a comprehensive, multi-layered literacy approach across grades PreK-2nd. The school will utilize evidence-based programs including daily 15-minute Heggerty phonemic awareness practice, K-2nd UFLI implementation with lessons and games, four times weekly Wonders Phonemic Awareness instruction, and increased Lexia usage as a system-wide tool. Additionally, students will receive targeted support through intervention blocks and small groups meeting four times weekly, leveled reading groups facilitated by instructional assistants and parent volunteers, alternative hands-on sound manipulation activities for Tier 2/3 students, and Letters and Sounds curriculum use in kindergarten through 2nd grade, all supported by multilingual and Safety Net assistance throughout the instructional day and school day.

Students in grades 3-5 will engage with daily Illustrative Math lessons aligned to the pacing guide, supplemented by five weekly DreamBox lessons for personalized practice and skill reinforcement. goals.strategies_summarized: Rachel Carson Elementary will foster a sense of belonging among grades 3-5 students through daily practices including student greeters upon arrival, classroom meetings, SOAR tickets for expected behavior, and student leadership opportunities, while complementing these efforts with monthly counseling lessons, school-wide assemblies, and principal coffee chats. The school will further reinforce positive culture through twice-monthly SOAR ticket winner celebrations, monthly Character Trait Falcon Parades, and special events such as Inclusive Schools Week in December and six or more PTSA-sponsored community events throughout the year. Additionally, accommodations such as early entrance to events for special education students and regular PTSA meetings will ensure an inclusive and welcoming environment where all students feel they belong at school.

goals.strategies_summarized: Clara Barton Elementary will implement a comprehensive, multi-tiered approach to support the 80 identified "Some Risk" or "High Risk" students in achieving aggressive or typical reading growth by May 2026. The school will establish structured literacy instruction across K-2 classrooms using Heggerty, UFLI, and Reading Wonders curriculum, while deploying differentiated small group instruction targeting specific reading skills and utilizing Lexia with fidelity for at-risk students, all supported by an MTSS Intervention Team that meets regularly with classroom teachers. Additionally, teachers will engage in professional learning on Sheltered Instruction Observation Protocol to support emerging language learners, collaborate through the Safety Net & ML intervention team to align Tier 1 instruction using developed planning tools, and use FastBridge data collected at mid-year and end of year to guide intervention development and monitor student progress throughout the school year.

goals.currentdata: Numerical concepts and operations are a foundational skill to apply to all areas of mathematics. Data analysis at the target level of the Screening to Intervention report on FastBridge indicates a relative weakness in this area relative to other math skills. The second-grade cohort had the lowest math data points of the six grades we support. The Building Leadership Team (BLT) has chosen to take a long-term targeted focus on this cohort of students to get them to grade level in math.

goals.strategies_summarized: Clara Barton Elementary will implement a comprehensive, multi-tiered approach to increase student belonging through universal social-emotional learning, targeted support for disconnected students, and environmental modifications. All K-5 classrooms will deliver 45 minutes of weekly SEL instruction during "Leadership Lab" to teach belonging and relationship-building strategies, while the school counselor and special education staff will provide additional small group support for students with greater needs; simultaneously, the school will use Panorama data and relationship mapping to identify and support individual students who feel disconnected. Additionally, the school will establish Peace Corners with sensory tools and regulatory resources in all instructional areas and at community events, help students identify their own connectivity language through morning meetings and student-created projects, and foster a welcoming environment where all students can experience a sense of belonging.

goals.strategies_summarized: Community School will weave inclusive language skills into established SEL lessons and morning meetings, with teachers collaborating at faculty meetings to co-create specific teaching opportunities within the curriculum, while also dedicating designated SEL time in each classroom and hosting whole school meetings to reinforce these concepts schoolwide. The school will utilize restorative conversations and think sheets to address instances of non-inclusive speech when they occur, and will maintain ongoing collaboration with the District Equity Department to ensure the approach is comprehensive and aligned with district initiatives. Through this multi-layered approach combining explicit instruction, peer accountability, and restorative practices, students will develop both the awareness to avoid non-inclusive speech and the skills to serve as upstanders when they encounter it from their peers.

goals.strategies_summarized: Emily Dickinson Elementary School will implement a comprehensive literacy improvement plan combining structured instruction, targeted interventions, and professional development to ensure all students demonstrate reading growth by spring 2026. The school will provide UFLI K-2 training and materials, conduct MTSS coaching cycles, and establish Safety Net support with collaboration between special education and general education teachers to serve identified students and small groups. Additionally, the school will deploy classified staff for small group and 1:1 support, schedule special education and general education office hours, integrate literacy intervention blocks into specialist schedules, allocate weekly class time for Lexia and Lexia Skill Builders, provide professional learning on small group instruction during All Day LEAP, and offer release days for learning walks and planning with literacy trainers, while classroom teachers track individual student growth goals using formative and summative assessments to differentiate instruction and support literacy development.

goals.strategies_summarized: To achieve a 5% increase in student Panorama scores for Emotional Regulation by spring 2026, Emily Dickinson Elementary School will implement a comprehensive, multi-faceted approach centered on daily emotional regulation practices and skill-building. Teachers will conduct daily check-ins using Zones of Regulation during classroom instruction and lead mindfulness and regulation strategies during morning meetings, while the school will reinforce consistent social-emotional language through monthly SOAR (PBIS) expectation videos and weekly Monday morning announcements featuring Character Strong scripts tied to school expectations. Additionally, the school will expand access to calming resources by establishing calm-down kits in classrooms, recess, and lunch areas, creating a dedicated Motor Room with trained staff and students, and administering the "Tell Me Tuesday" survey as a diagnostic tool to monitor progress and gather student feedback throughout the year.

goals.outcome: 90% or more of Kindergarten, 1st , 2nd and 3rd grade students will demonstrate minimal to low risk in all components as measured by FastBridge reading on the Screening-to-Intervention (s2i) Report by Spring of 2026.
goals.currentdata: Preventing any student in grades K-2 from demonstrating high risk on the FastBridge End of Year assessments allows for early identification and targeted intervention. This proactive approach helps address reading difficulties before they become more entrenched, reducing long-term learning gaps. Monitoring growth through the Screening to Intervention Report ensures that instruction is responsive and tailored to each student’s needs, promoting equitable learning opportunities. Looking at Fastbridge data, there are 13 students (K- 3rd) demonstrating some to high risk. Early intervention with targeted phonics instruction will help us achieve this goal.

goals.strategies_summarized: Discovery Community School will implement a comprehensive, multi-tiered literacy approach across kindergarten through second grade to achieve this reading proficiency goal. Teachers will deliver daily explicit phonics and phonemic awareness instruction through both whole-class Heggerty lessons (10-15 minutes daily with Safety Net teacher collaboration in K-1-2) and explicit phonics sequences embedded in Wonders instruction, with implementation verified through administrative observations. Additionally, the school will provide targeted Tier 2 small group differentiated instruction using Wonders curricular tools and the UFLI curriculum to address students with risk indicators in phonemic awareness, phonics, and fluency, with progress monitored through FastBridge intervention plans and documented through group rosters and lesson plans.

goals.outcome: Students who demonstrated some or high risk on the beginning of year FastBridge reading assessments will show typical to aggressive growth by Spring of 2026 as measured on the FastBridge Group Growth Report.
goals.currentdata: When students get to middle school, there is a huge shift to reading to learn, versus learning to read. Our current data shows that students grew by a median growth percentile of 53 on the Spring 2025 ELA SBA, 53 on the Spring 2024 ELA SBA and 62 on the Spring 2023 ELA SBA. This means that just about half of our students are growing less than their same age peers with similar score profiles throughout the state. This same data trend is also evident in FastBridge Growth Percentile data from the 2024-2025 school year.

goals.strategies_summarized: Discovery Community School will review FastBridge growth data during winter assessments to identify student strengths and weaknesses, then update their watch list to address the most current needs of at-risk readers. The school will implement flexible small groups during WINN time using targeted FastBridge resources and evidence-based instructional strategies including multi-sensory instruction, modeling, and guided practices tailored to individual student needs. Additionally, the team will provide clear success criteria for assignment progression, facilitate peer tutoring and collaboration among same-level peers, and maintain personalized engagement to support typical to aggressive reading growth by Spring 2026.

goals.outcome: The percentage of students who respond favorably to the Panorama Survey in the Spring of 2026 in the Emotional Regulation category will increase by 10% or more in the overall category and for each question within the category
goals.currentdata: Results of the Panorama Survey in the Spring of 2025, indicate that 66% of 3rd, 4th and 5th grade students responded favorably in the “Emotional Regulation” category. This percentage does not include neutral responses. The breakdown of favorable responses by question is below, percentages do not include neutral responses: • How often are you able to control your emotions when you need to? 67% responded favorably • How often are you able to pull yourself out of a bad mood? 64% responded favorably • Once you get upset, how often can you get yourself to relax? 58% responded favorably • When things go wrong for you, how calm are you able to stay?73%

strategies.action: Put in place a multi-tiered instructional system available to all students to provide increasing levels of behavioral and social- emotional instruction and support for students when needed.
strategies.measures: Counseling Groups Alternate Recess Options Zones of Regulation Lessons Calming Corners Attendance logs

goals.strategies_summarized: Discovery Community School will implement a multi-tiered instructional system designed to support all students' emotional regulation through increasingly intensive interventions tailored to individual needs. This system will include Zones of Regulation lessons integrated into instruction, the establishment of calming corners as accessible resources, alternative recess options to meet diverse student needs, and counseling groups for students requiring targeted support, with attendance logs maintained to monitor participation and progress. By providing these layered behavioral and social-emotional supports, the school aims to foster greater emotional regulation skills and increase the percentage of students responding favorably to the Panorama Survey's Emotional Regulation category by at least 10% by Spring 2026.

goals.strategies_summarized: To achieve a 10% growth in phonics and reading comprehension scores by Spring 2026, Einstein Elementary School will implement small group instruction across all grades supported by monthly progress monitoring through FastBridge assessments, CORE letter sound assessments, and unit assessments, while supplementing with whole group Heggerty phonics instruction in grades K-2 and weekly UFLI assessments. Additionally, the school will ensure all students complete a minimum of 40 minutes of Lexia per week and will provide targeted support through ML, Safety Net, and Special Education services that include progress monitoring, WIDA assessments, fluency CBM, SIPPS, and Wonderworks for grades 4-5 to address individual student needs in phonics and reading comprehension. These multi-layered interventions will be continuously monitored through various formative assessments including Lexia progress data, Fastbridge weekly reading formative assessments, and LWSD unit summative assessments to ensure students are progressing toward the established growth targets.

goals.strategies_summarized: Einstein Elementary School will pursue a comprehensive approach to achieve 10% growth in math achievement across all grade levels by Spring 2026, partnering with Dr. Anita Lenges from the University of Washington to enhance the student experience in math through the implementation of evidence-based instructional strategies. The school will integrate 10-15 minute Number Talks into daily math instruction across all grades while ensuring consistent use of Illustrative Math warm-ups focused on number relationships and operations, with fidelity monitored through monthly classroom walkthroughs, peer observations, and student work samples. Additionally, the school will provide professional development sessions focused on number sense, Number Talks, and fluency-building strategies, with implementation tracked through coaching cycles, teacher surveys, and lesson plan reviews to ensure sustained and effective instructional improvement.

goals.strategies_summarized: Ella Baker Elementary will implement a comprehensive, data-driven literacy improvement plan utilizing FastBridge assessments three times per year to identify K-5 low-income students needing support, combined with twice-monthly MTSS meetings and systematic progress monitoring to inform instructional decisions. All staff will implement evidence-based Tier 1 and Tier 2 interventions, including daily Haggerty phonemic awareness instruction for K-2 students, daily UFLI small group instruction, weekly Lexia practice (2-3 times weekly for 40 minutes), and the Read Naturally program for identified 2-5 grade students, supported by teacher training from the Instructional Coach and a collaborative 3-year plan ensuring coordinated instruction between classroom teachers, intervention specialists, and special education staff. Through this integrated approach combining systematic assessment, targeted instruction, and collaborative data-based decision-making, the school aims to move 75% of low-income K-5 students to "No" or "Low Risk" status on FastBridge by Spring 2027.

goals.strategies_summarized: Ella Baker Elementary will implement a comprehensive, data-driven approach to improve early reading outcomes for K-5 low-income students by establishing Tier 1 foundational practices including three yearly FastBridge assessments, daily use of Illustrative Mathematics (IM) routines with fidelity monitored through administrative observations and implementation rubrics, and 2-3 weekly DreamBox sessions with teacher data monitoring. Additionally, the school will conduct bi-annual reviews of IM pacing guides and essential lessons using unit assessments and quick checks to inform instruction, while simultaneously providing Tier 1 and 2 small group instruction based on ongoing formative and summative assessment data, with progress tracked through FIA data-based decision-making protocols to ensure students reach "No" or "Low Risk" status on FastBridge by Spring 2027.

goals.strategies_summarized: Ella Baker Elementary will implement a comprehensive, multi-tiered approach to foster belonging and self-acceptance among K-5 students through explicit instruction of their school motto "Be Kind. Be Brave. Be You. Be the Change," with 100% of teachers reinforcing these values through daily classroom meetings, literature, and identity-building strategies. The school will create intentional practices across all classrooms and grade-level "dens" that emphasize belonging, including multiple student leadership opportunities, three schoolwide events annually, and targeted support through the Baker Bear Club for students demonstrating social challenges. Additionally, the school will use Panorama assessment data to identify students needing additional support, with counselors and community instructional specialists conducting monthly data reviews and providing targeted interventions, while also integrating social-emotional character education daily and supporting new students through counseling groups and principal meet-and-greets to ensure all students feel welcomed and valued.
goals.engagement_strategies: Students set SECD goals during Family Connection Meetings. Our teachers have developed a set of questions to gather information about their families, the students, and what is important to them. At Partnering with Families, we engage families in community circles and teach them about restorative practices. We host a new family night that focuses on community building, SECD work, restorative practices, and we gather input from families on our partnership. We host 3 listening sessions at Redmond Ridge Apartments to gather input and partner with families.

goals.strategies_summarized: Explorer Community School will implement a comprehensive, multi-tiered approach to early literacy instruction and intervention for K-2 students, beginning with evidence-based programs including Heggerty phonological awareness training and UFLi small group instruction, supported by ongoing MTSS coaching cycles and weekly special education/general education collaboration meetings. The school will establish dedicated literacy intervention blocks within the specialist schedule, create flexible small group instruction calendars tailored to individual student needs, and leverage parent volunteers to provide one-on-one reteaching of challenging concepts through a structured weekly volunteer schedule. Additionally, students will receive weekly Lexia and Lexia Skill Builders practice time in class, while families will be engaged through regular parent-teacher conferences, literacy meetings with progress updates, and a Technology and School Resources Connection Event to ensure consistent support both at school and at home.

goals.strategies_summarized: Explorer Community School will implement a comprehensive literacy initiative combining evidence-based instructional programs (UFLI, Heggerty, and Lexia) with systematic support structures to ensure all students demonstrate reading growth by spring 2026. The school will provide ongoing professional development through monthly PLC meetings and MTSS coaching cycles while establishing collaborative spaces such as weekly Special Education/General Education office hours and creating flexible small group instruction tailored to individual student needs. Additionally, the school will leverage parent volunteers for one-on-one reteaching and dedicate time within specialist schedules for intensive literacy intervention blocks to address gaps and support student progress on the FastBridge reading assessment.

goals.strategies_summarized: To achieve a 5% increase in student Panorama scores for Emotional Regulation by spring 2026, Explorer Community School will implement a comprehensive approach centered on daily regulation practices and consistent social-emotional learning instruction. Teachers will conduct daily check-ins using Zones of Regulation during classroom instruction and lead mindfulness/regulation strategies during morning meetings, with progress monitored through the "Tell Me Tuesday" survey and teacher feedback. Additionally, the school will reinforce common social-emotional language school-wide through monthly SOAR (PBIS) expectation videos, weekly Monday morning announcements featuring SEL content tied to school expectations, and the establishment of accessible calm-down spaces including classroom kits, a dedicated Motor Room, and sensory areas during recess and lunch to support student regulation.

Students in grades 3rd-5th identified as ‘at risk’ in phonemic awareness will make measurable growth towards scoring in a proficient category as measured by the end-of-year FastBridge universal screening tool.
goals.currentdata: Phonics and phonemic awareness are foundational components for students learning to read. Historic and beginning-of-year Screening-to-Intervention reports regarding FastBridge reading assessments identified phonics as a relative growth area in reading comparative to other foundational components.

goals.strategies_summarized: Benjamin Franklin Elementary School will implement a comprehensive, multi-tiered literacy approach to support phonics and phonemic awareness growth for at-risk students in grades K-5. The school will provide explicit and systematic phonics instruction using Wonders curriculum for all students, supplemented by Tier 2 small group instruction for those in general education classrooms, while establishing targeted interventions through full UFLI implementation in grades K-2 and Bridge the Gap for phonemic awareness in grades 4-5, all supported by MTSS processes to identify and monitor at-risk learners. Progress will be tracked through three annual FastBridge universal screenings, classroom observations, and diagnostic assessments to ensure measurable growth toward proficiency by year-end.

goals.outcome: Students will demonstrate overall growth in their math fact fluency, as well as through consistent engagement in differentiated math centers that address individual needs and provide opportunities for targeted practice as measured by the FastBridge assessment. Focusing on centers-based fluency activities and Thinking Classroom strategies students will participate in rich, collaborative problem solving that promotes reasoning and amplifies/increases student voice.
goals.currentdata: Fluency and automaticity are keys to increasing, achieving and sustaining student growth and the foundational levels of elementary math. Referencing historical and fall of 2025 FastBridge screening data, increasing our fluency will increase all other areas of math achievement. Fluency is amongst the lowest score on the Screening to Intervention reports for each of our grade levels, despite being very high as a whole.

strategies.action: Decrease emphasis and dependency on math workbooks
strategies.measures: Increased visibility and observability of collaborative thinking tasks and less frequent creation and dependency on math workbooks to teach/reinforce math.

strategies.action: Differentiated instruction through math centers in the classroom, each designed to address different skill levels and learning styles.
strategies.measures: Strategies and learning to deepen staff ability to emphasize learning and content for differentiation in math instruction and student learning (i.e. routines and structure of centers, intentional student grouping, incorporating SIOP, GLAD and Building Thinking Classrooms strategies).

strategies.action: Utilization of math centers as a regular part of math blocks.
strategies.measures: Observed utilization and intentional planning of centers within all grade level math blocks.

strategies.action: Continued focus on consistent math language routines and vocabulary.
strategies.measures: Focus on strategies and learning to deepen staff ability to emphasize learning and content for vocabulary in math instruction and student learning (i.e. incorporating math word wall). Measure for implementation, fidelity, and effectiveness across informal and formal classroom observations.

strategies.action: Incorporation of Thinking Classroom tasks designed to align to our adopted math standards and our curriculum.
strategies.measures: Observable utilization with informal and formal classroom observations and narrative descriptions from grade level teams documenting progress and advancement towards task design and implementation.

goals.strategies_summarized: Benjamin Franklin Elementary School will shift their math instruction approach by decreasing reliance on workbooks in favor of collaborative, thinking-based tasks while establishing math centers as a regular, integral component of daily math blocks designed to differentiate instruction and address diverse skill levels and learning styles. To support this transformation, staff will deepen their instructional practices through professional learning focused on center routines, intentional student grouping, and integration of SIOP, GLAD, and Building Thinking Classroom strategies, while simultaneously emphasizing consistent math language routines and vocabulary development through tools such as math word walls. Progress will be monitored through classroom observations and grade-level documentation, ensuring fidelity of implementation and measuring the effectiveness of these center-based and thinking-focused activities in building student math fact fluency and promoting collaborative problem-solving and student voice.

goals.outcome: Increased opportunities for families to provide voice and feedback while also participating in school-based decision-making and governance. Additionally, we will have an explicit focus on increasing sense of belonging amongst our staff members.
goals.currentdata: • TFI data from the Fall of 2025 documents 8.1 Family Collaboration as a relative growth area. 9.2 LEA Address Barriers documents a growth opportunity this year and is a focus of professional learning being prioritized by our district this year. • Spring of 2025 Staff Panorama data documents sense of belonging as a relative area of growth for instructional and non-instructional staff members.

goals.strategies_summarized: Benjamin Franklin Elementary School will strengthen family voice and participation through multiple coordinated efforts, including aligning family connection meetings for a more universal experience, recruiting parent representation on school leadership teams, and increasing family participation in the annual Panorama survey to capture more diverse perspectives. Additionally, the BLT and BEI teams will intentionally incorporate family feedback into their planning processes, while dedicated listening sessions with non-instructional staff will amplify their voices and gather ideas for improvement. To foster a stronger sense of belonging among all staff members, the school will promote inclusivity in scheduling events and activities, ensuring that these gatherings are accessible and welcoming to the entire school community.

goals.strategies_summarized: Robert Frost Elementary School will implement a comprehensive, multi-tiered literacy approach to achieve this growth goal, beginning with regular small group instruction embedded in the core literacy block with daily rotations for targeted students, supported by dedicated intervention specialists providing daily small group instruction to at-risk students identified through biweekly progress monitoring. The school will strengthen instructional practices through coaching and professional learning focused on Visible Learning and the LWSD Instructional Playbook, utilizing FastBridge S2I reporting data to identify target skills and inform both core and intervention instruction, with two half-day planning sessions each semester for teachers to design lessons aligned to these guidelines. Additionally, the school will employ research-based interventions including UFLI and Heggerty lessons with fidelity across K-3, extend intervention block scheduling to provide increased instructional time, and leverage co-teaching and collaborative coaching among Title 1, MTSS, and Safety Net Specialists, with regular data meetings and administrator walk-throughs to monitor implementation and adjust support as needed.

goals.strategies_summarized: Robert Frost Elementary School will implement a comprehensive, multi-faceted approach to achieve 85% student growth in mathematics by establishing consistent daily grade-level instruction with common planning blocks for alignment, utilizing Illustrative Math games and centers alongside small group reteaching to address individual student needs. Teachers will employ concrete manipulatives and visual representations across all classrooms while participating in LEAP professional learning focused on Building Thinking Classrooms, including a book study with peer observations and an extended intervention block to provide additional instructional time. Additionally, teacher teams will attend professional development at PSESD in March 2026 and participate in two half-day PLC planning sessions using FastBridge and SBA data to design targeted lessons that embed Building Thinking Classrooms instructional practices, ensuring all students receive high-quality, differentiated mathematics instruction.

goals.focus_area: Sense of Belonging and Emotional Regulation
goals.outcome: We believe that all students must be safe and feel a sense of belonging if they are to succeed. It is our responsibility to create safe and inclusive learning communities where all students can thrive. Growth in the area of Emotional Regulation: Challenging Feelings, such as worry, anger, and sadness. This was also a comparatively higher impact area for students identifying as female and greater impact for students identifying as Hispanic/Latinx Female
goals.currentdata: The results of the Panorama Student Survey Data (Spring 2025) identified that: • Frost students responded with a higher percentage (92%) of positive responses in Supportive Relationships than the district average and up 3% from 2024. • Frost students scored 7 percentage points lower than the average for the Lake Washington School District on Challenging Feelings, such as worry, anger, and sadness. This was also a comparatively higher impact area for students identifying as female and greater impact for students identifying as Hispanic/Latinx Female.

goals.strategies_summarized: Robert Frost Elementary School will implement a comprehensive, multi-layered approach to support emotional regulation and create a sense of belonging for all students, particularly those identifying as female and Hispanic/Latinx female. Staff will receive professional learning on trauma-sensitive practices and brain research from Dr. Shotland, with implementation of evidence-based strategies integrated into the schoolwide PBIS system, while designated SEL time will be structured across grade levels to deliver the Purposeful People and Second Step curriculum. Additionally, recess and lunchroom supervisors will apply de-escalation and emotional regulation strategies aligned with the SEL curriculum, the school counselor will provide small-group interventions using Second Step, and a 4th and 5th Grade Student Council will be established to amplify student voice—with success measured through decreased office and recess referrals, administrative walkthroughs, curriculum-based assessments, and student listening sessions.

goals.strategies_summarized: Juanita Elementary School will implement a comprehensive literacy approach across K-5 by having teachers collaborate horizontally and vertically to teach literacy standards with fidelity using Wonders, UFLI, and Heggerty while integrating strategies from the LWSD Instructional Playbook. Students will engage with research-based Lexia technology to support literacy development, and K-5 teachers will regularly analyze assessment data from Wonders Unit Assessments, UFLI, Heggerty, and other measures to adjust instruction, create flexible grouping, and differentiate learning based on individual student performance and needs. Teachers and interventionists will use these data insights to plan targeted interventions informed by Universal Design for Learning principles, ensuring all students receive the support necessary to meet or exceed standards by Spring 2026.

goals.strategies_summarized: To achieve the goal of 80% of K-5th grade students scoring at or above standard by Spring 2026, Juanita Elementary School will implement a comprehensive mathematics improvement plan focused on number sense, multiplication proficiency, and differentiated instruction. Teachers will engage in professional development on small group instruction and inquiry-based math through Building Thinking Classrooms, while utilizing DreamBox technology and elements of Universal Design for Learning (UDL) and the LWSD Instructional Playbook to create flexible grouping and differentiated lessons. Additionally, teachers will use formative data from IM Unit Assessments and Cool Down sections to regularly evaluate student performance, reflect on outcomes, and adjust instruction to meet individual student needs.
goals.engagement_strategies: Teachers will engage students and their families in collaborative setting and monitoring mathematics goals through respectful, culturally responsive practices that honor the diverse strengths of our school community. Our goal is to build meaningful, two-way partnerships that empower families to support math learning at home in ways that feel natural, inclusive, and connected to daily life. To strengthen these partnerships, we will: • Provide math fluency resources, including at-home games, weekly fluency logs, and access to IM (Illustrative Mathematics) family letters to help families understand unit goals and vocabulary. • Share pictures and examples of “math in action” from classrooms and school events to illustrate what high-quality math learning looks like. • Collaborate with families to build math automaticity, offering simple practice routines and strategies that can be incorporated into home life. • Send home IM Unit Family Information and website links that support grade-level math concepts. • Invite families to share photos of math in their real lives, such as cooking, budgeting, gardening, or building—celebrating the many cultural and everyday ways math shows up at home. • Promote accessible family math games such as Yahtzee, cribbage, and other culturally relevant games that support counting, patterning, probability, and strategic thinking. • Host class visits with math experts in the community—such as bakers, carpenters, engineers, gamers, or artists—to show real- world applications of mathematical thinking. • Encourage families to use math in daily routines, such as cooking measurements, time management, comparing prices, or planning schedules, reinforcing math as a practical life skill. Through these collaborative strategies, we aim to create a math learning community where students see themselves as capable mathematicians and families feel confident, supported, and valued as partners in their child’s mathematical growth.

goals.strategies_summarized: To achieve equity, Juanita Elementary School will implement a comprehensive approach centered on building students' social-emotional competencies and fostering inclusive relationships. All staff will engage in trauma-informed practices, culturally responsive teaching, and explicit instruction in respectful interactions, while simultaneously supporting students' self-regulation through daily grounding strategies and frequent classroom meetings focused on resiliency and problem-solving. Success will be measured through tracking the percentage of staff implementing these practices, the number of students reporting increased positive peer connections, and the frequency of classroom meetings and self-regulating activities across all grade levels.
goals.engagement_strategies: Staff will actively engage families in Social-Emotional Learning by providing accessible, culturally responsive, and meaningful opportunities for collaboration. Our goal is to strengthen the home–school connection and empower families to reinforce SEL skills in ways that reflect their values, traditions, and lived experiences. To deepen SEL partnerships with families, we will: • Host SEL-focused learning opportunities during Open House, curriculum nights, and PTA meetings to build shared understanding of core SEL skills and practices. • Share family-friendly strategies and resources through newsletters, videos, and classroom updates to support SEL development at home. • Invite families to share what respect looks like in their family, helping students recognize diverse cultural expressions of kindness, responsibility, and care. • Encourage families to use movies, videos, and short stories that promote positive SEL messages, providing examples and recommendations to help spark meaningful conversations at home. • Offer opportunities for families to share how they celebrate important traditions, supporting cultural awareness, belonging, and identity development across the school community. • Provide platforms for families to share about their careers and areas of expertise, highlighting SEL skills such as teamwork, collaboration, resilience, and problem-solving in real-life contexts. Through these ongoing efforts, we aim to create a school culture where students feel understood, supported, and connected, and where families are valued as essential partners in nurturing social-emotional development.

goals.strategies_summarized: To achieve 80% of students making aggressive, typical, or modest growth in reading and increasing the number of students categorized as low risk on Fastbridge assessments, Helen Keller Elementary will implement a comprehensive, grade-level approach utilizing evidence-based curricula and family engagement strategies. Kindergarten through 2nd grade will use UFLI and Heggerty with co-teaching and family engagement through goal-setting conferences and digital platforms like SeeSaw, while 3rd through 5th grades will employ Safety Net collaboration, PLC conversations focused on data analysis, intervention and enrichment grouping, and weekly family communications. Administrative support will include observational feedback for reading interventions, participation in PLCs, continuous tracking of student growth data, and direct engagement with families of students not on track, while Special Education will integrate UFLI as an intervention curriculum and collaborate with general education teachers to build foundational reading skills and executive functioning.

goals.strategies_summarized: Helen Keller Elementary will implement a comprehensive, school-wide approach to math growth across all grade levels, beginning with kindergarten through second grade teachers co-creating math goals with families through their preferred communication methods (in-person, phone, or Teams) while collaborating with the instructional coach and meeting regularly as PLCs to review progress. Third grade will emphasize data-driven PLC conversations and critical thinking strategies with family engagement through assessment input forms, while fourth and fifth grades will utilize Building Thinking Classrooms strategies alongside intervention and enrichment groups supported by weekly family communications. Administration and specialists will provide observational feedback, track student growth data, engage in PLCs, and communicate with families of at-risk students, while special education teachers will support the initiative through Building Thinking Classrooms book studies, executive functioning skill-building, and collaboration with general education teachers and preschool programs to ensure foundational mathematics readiness.

goals.focus_area: Elevating Parent Voice of Black Students through Family Engagement
goals.outcome: By June 2026, 80% of Black/Black-Hispanic/Black two or more races students at Keller will demonstrate growth in social-emotional competencies related to belonging, self-efficacy, and school connectedness, as measured by SEL survey indicators, Panorama SEL data, and behavioral data (office referrals, proactive check-ins, attendance). To support this, Keller will implement family partnership practices that elevate Black parent voice, including co-constructing what belonging looks like and sounds like and creating opportunities for families to share experiences that inform school practices. Data from Black family feedback will be used to co-design at least two schoolwide initiatives to improve student belonging and agency.

goals.strategies_summarized: Helen Keller Elementary will establish a Parent Equity Team and Teacher Equity Team to co-construct meaningful definitions of belonging with Black families and design schoolwide initiatives that center student agency and connectedness. The school will partner with the "And Still We Rise" initiative and engage a Harvard partnership led by Dr. Karen Mapp to guide the Building Leadership Team in implementing evidence-based practices that elevate Black parent voice and incorporate family feedback into school operations. Additionally, whole staff professional development will equip teachers with the knowledge and skills to support social-emotional growth, while progress will be monitored through SEL survey indicators, Panorama data, and behavioral metrics including office referrals, attendance, and proactive check-ins.

goals.strategies_summarized: Peter Kirk Elementary will implement a comprehensive Multi-Tiered System of Supports (MTSS) across Grades K-5, with Tier 1 instruction grounded in UFLI implementation and grade-level standards, Tier 2 small group interventions using data-directed instruction through Heggerty and UFLI during dedicated WINN blocks, and Tier 3 targeted services for students with IEPs or multilingual learner needs. To support these instructional initiatives, the school will provide dedicated professional learning through district-provided UFLI training, partnerships with Lake Washington School District TOSAs for coaching on small group instruction and inquiry-based practices, staff-led professional learning on data-centered PLC practices, and learning walks to observe literacy instruction at other elementary schools. Building-based systems will include a unified block schedule K-5 that aligns instructional and intervention blocks and streamlined classified schedules to maximize additional support services, while progress will be monitored through classroom observations, PLC meeting documentation, coaching cycle records, and ongoing schedule adjustments.

goals.strategies_summarized: Peter Kirk Elementary will implement a comprehensive, multi-tiered approach to mathematics instruction and intervention, beginning with Tier 1 supports that deliver the Illustrative Math inquiry-based curriculum with fidelity while implementing Building Thinking Classrooms to enhance engagement and mathematical discourse, alongside consistent language supports for English learners. Complementary Tier 2 supports will utilize curriculum maps and skills strands to provide targeted just-in-time interventions, strategic WINN time for small group instruction, and math centers focused on fluency and application practice. To ensure successful implementation, the school will dedicate substantial professional learning time to deepen staff understanding of inquiry-based instruction and Building Thinking Classrooms through book studies and coaching cycles in partnership with district TOSAs, while establishing building-based systems including a K-5 block schedule that aligns instructional and intervention blocks and streamlines classified schedules to maximize support for students, particularly those identified as low-income.
goals.engagement_strategies: - Share the SIP goal at PTSA general membership meeting and provide information about inquiry-based math instruction. - School and PTSA-sponsored events, such as Math Night, enrichment opportunities and assemblies, STEM program, etc are aligned to school improvement plan. - Organized efforts – PTSA general membership meeting, teacher newsletters, principal’s message – to share with families the ‘why’ behind inquiry-based instruction and the research-based benefits for students. This can include an overview of what families can expect from instruction to look like in the classroom and how they can best support at home. - Host Math focus groups, defining experiential learning within a Building Thinking Classrooms model and conversation tied to math identity and their experiences with math learning/instruction.

goals.focus_area: Sense of Belonging, Supportive Relationships, Teacher-Student Relationships
goals.outcome: Improve students’ overall Sense of Belonging from 60% to 70% as measured by an increase in favorable responses on survey questions associated with Sense of Belonging and Supportive Relationships.
goals.currentdata: Panorama Data from the Spring of 2025 continued a trend of six consecutive survey windows showing a decline in or flat growth in student’s Sense of Belonging. Overall Sense of Belonging: Spring 2025: 60% Fall 2024: 60% Spring 2024: 64% Fall 2023: 66% Spring 2023: 67% Fall 2022: 69% Related survey question strands impacting student sense of belonging are Supportive Relationships and Teacher-Student Relationships. Favorable responses to survey questions falling under Supportive relationships place Peter Kirk in the bottom quintile when compared with other Lake Washington School District elementary schools. Supportive Relationships: One specific survey item saw a 5% decrease, down to 74%, from the previous survey: Do you have a teacher or other adult from school who you can count on to help you, no matter what? Teacher-Student Relationships: Two survey items provide valuable insight into the student experience: How respectful are your teachers towards you? (10% decrease) When your teacher asks, “How are you?”, how often do you feel that they really want to know you answer? (2% decrease)

Additionally, the school will invest in professional learning for staff through the TIES Center's Creating Communities of Belonging training, E-M-R training, and culturally responsive teaching workshops to ensure all adults can foster belonging, while simultaneously expanding student leadership opportunities through peer mentoring, WingMates programs, and clubs, and strengthening community partnerships with the PTSA to host inclusive recess activities and reinvigorate parent volunteering through the Co-pilot program. goals.strategies_summarized: Lakeview Elementary School will implement a comprehensive, multi-tiered literacy approach to close the proficiency gap between K/1st and 2-5 low-income students. Tier 1 instruction will include daily explicit use of Wonders curriculum and Heggerty/UFLI phonics instruction (K-2), supplemented by Lexia practice 2-3 times weekly, with all students assessed three times yearly using Fastbridge to identify risk indicators. For students requiring additional support, Tier 2 and 3 small group, differentiated instruction will target phonemic awareness, phonics, and fluency using Wonders and UFLI curricular tools, supported by collaboration between classroom teachers and intervention staff, coaching cycles with the MTSS coach, and ongoing cycles of inquiry through grade-level PLCs where progress monitoring is documented. Additionally, staff will engage in literacy-focused professional development and learning walks facilitated by the MTSS coach, while an MTSS Intervention Team will meet on rotating 6-week cycles to monitor progress and adjust interventions as needed.

goals.outcome: Close proficiency gap that currently exists between K/1st and 2-5 low-income students as measured by Fastbridge assessment (early math for K-1 and aReading for 2-5).
goals.currentdata: According to Fall 2025 Fastbridge Screener data: • 46% of students identified as low income scored proficiently (low or minimal risk) on the earlymath assessment with Kindergarten and 1st grade students in comparison to 92% of students categorized as non-low income. • 51% of students identified as low income scored proficiently (low or minimal risk) on the aMath assessment with 2nd-5th grade students in comparison to 90% of students categorized as non low-income. 13.2% of our total student population is low income. There is a disproportionate number of students identified as low income. There is also intersectionality of students receiving special education services and multilingual learners who also qualify for low income, further adding to the disproportionality. 24.6% of students identified as low income also receive special education services. 27.9% of students identified as low income are also multilingual learners.

goals.strategies_summarized: Lakeview Elementary School will implement a comprehensive, multi-tiered approach to close the proficiency gap between K/1st and 2-5 low-income students through regular assessment, enhanced instructional practices, and targeted interventions. The school will administer Fastbridge assessments three times yearly to monitor progress, provide daily instruction using Illustrative Mathematics (IM) routines with support materials, and offer Dreambox learning opportunities 2-3 times weekly, with teachers monitoring student data for intervention needs. Additionally, the school will conduct bi-annual reviews of IM pacing guides and essential lessons through grade-level PLC collaboration; implement differentiated learning strategies informed by Fastbridge data and PLC analysis; deliver targeted professional development in math instruction, standards unpacking, and building thinking classrooms; and facilitate MTSS intervention team meetings on six-week cycles with learning walks led by an MTSS coach to ensure consistent implementation and fidelity across classrooms.

goals.outcome: All students will improve how they manage challenging feelings from 67% to 78% as measured by panorama data, youth needs screener data, student reflection, and classroom observations.
goals.currentdata: According to Fall 2025 Panorama data: • 70% of students responded favorably (measured as almost never or once in a while) when asked the question “during the past week, how often did you feel lonely?”. 30% of students responded as sometimes (17%), frequently (8%), and almost always (5%). • 65% of students responded favorably (measured as almost never or once in a while) when asked the question “during the past week, how often did you feel sad?”. 35% of students responded as sometimes (25%), frequently (6%), and almost always (3%). • 64% of students responded favorably (measured as almost never or once in a while) when asked the question “during the past week, how often did you feel worried?”. 36% of students responded as sometimes (25%), frequently (6%), and almost always (5%). • 67% of students responded favorably (measured as almost never or once in a while) when asked the question “during the past week, how often did you feel mad?”. 33% of students responded as sometimes (22%), frequently (9%), and almost always (2%).

goals.strategies_summarized: Lakeview Elementary School will implement a comprehensive, multi-tiered approach to help all students improve their management of challenging feelings. At the Tier 1 level, the school will establish dedicated time for explicit daily SEL instruction using the Purposeful People curriculum, create and implement PBIS team-designed lessons and student self-reflections focused on emotions like sadness, worry, anger, and loneliness, and provide professional development to teachers on equity, inclusion, and belonging through evidence-based practices like EMR and UDL. Additionally, the school will administer Character Strong and PBIS screeners twice yearly to identify student needs, use screener and Panorama data to drive targeted Tier 2 small group counseling interventions, hold regular MTSS meetings to monitor progress, teach and reinforce schoolwide expectations throughout the year, and strengthen family partnerships through SEL community events, parent conferences, and ongoing communication about student wellbeing and progress. All of these actions will be measured through implementation data, classroom observations, student reflection data, and family and teacher feedback to ensure students progress from 67% to 78% in managing challenging feelings.

goals.strategies_summarized: Horace Mann Elementary School will implement science-based reading instruction through block scheduling, differentiated small group instruction, and evidence-based curricular materials, while systematically teaching phonics in K-2 using Heggerty and UFLI programs supported by regular fluency monitoring through Lexia and classroom-level data collection. Teachers will engage in professional learning cycles and coaching inquiries focused on standards clarity, rigor, and best practices for tiered interventions, with progress tracked through meeting minutes, observation notes, and collaborative grade-level data analysis. Additionally, the school will expand enrichment opportunities for advanced learners through choice projects and novel studies while allocating building funds to support ongoing professional development in literacy, with success measured through FastBridge assessments and classroom-based monitoring of student progress and growth.

goals.strategies_summarized: Horace Mann Elementary School will achieve the goal of 100% of students demonstrating one year's growth through a comprehensive approach that combines enhanced instructional practices with targeted support systems. Teachers will engage in professional learning and inquiry cycles focused on standards clarity, mathematical thinking, and higher-order thinking tasks, with implementation supported through coaching cycles and classroom observations of strategies such as number talks and problem-solving tasks. Additionally, the school will provide systematic Tier 1, 2, and 3 instruction through small group intervention blocks (WINN) with targeted individual supports, enrichment opportunities via choice projects and challenge problems, and allocated budget resources to sustain these professional learning initiatives, all measured through formative and summative assessment data, intervention plans, and grade-level data.

goals.strategies_summarized: Horace Mann Elementary School will implement a comprehensive approach to increase student use of self-regulation strategies by developing shared agreements about SEL block activities with a menu of options, designing and piloting common lessons during these blocks, and providing professional learning on community circles and restorative practices to support implementation. Additionally, the school will schedule regular events bringing together students from Quest programs to reinforce these strategies in a collaborative setting. Progress will be monitored through review of implementation plans, notes from planning meetings, student feedback on events, and professional learning agendas to ensure consistent integration of self-regulation strategies across the school.

goals.currentdata: Literacy goals were created based upon reading/writing teacher pre-assessment data, historical performance, developmental needs, and identification of students not at standard on state (SBA) and district (FastBridge) assessments. Additional consideration was given to areas on the SBA where students performed lower relative to other portions of the test, per target data information. Action items were created to support growth within these goal areas, providing challenge and rigor for all students, focusing on intervention efforts, and emphasizing collaboration amongst staff in support of all students in the area of Literacy.
