goals.strategies_summarized: Christa McAuliffe Elementary will achieve 95% proficiency in grades 3-5 ELA by implementing a comprehensive, multi-faceted literacy improvement plan centered on data-driven instruction and targeted skill development. Grade level teams will analyze 2025 SBA target data to focus instruction on identified underperforming areas in reading and writing, while all K-5 teachers will participate in professional learning around writing emphasis areas (sentence structure, paragraphing, text evidence, and rubric alignment), incorporate culturally responsive teaching strategies, and implement regular intervention blocks supported by evidence-based programs including Heggerty, UFLI, Secret Stories, Lexia, and Writing Revolution strategies. Additionally, teachers will engage in vertical teaming to provide explicit instruction in organizational structure and text evidence, utilize the Instructional Coach for ongoing collaboration and professional development in literacy instruction and word work, and implement consistent calibration of grading processes and assessment practices across all grade levels.

goals.strategies_summarized: Christa McAuliffe Elementary will implement a comprehensive, multi-faceted approach to improve mathematics achievement by targeting specific areas of underperformance identified in SBA data, with grade-level teams focusing instruction on Concepts and Procedures across grades 3–5. The school will leverage LEAP collaborative time to build teacher capacity in math fact fluency, utilize supplemental resources such as Dreambox and IM strategies, and employ FastBridge assessment data to inform differentiated instruction. Additionally, the school will establish regular intervention block schedules with flexible small groups supported by parent volunteers and instructional aides, while teachers in grades 4–5 will assign intentional homework targeting specific skills, and special education teachers will coordinate schedules to ensure all students receive appropriate math support.

goals.outcome: 75% of students in grades 3 – 5 will respond favorably in Emotional Regulation as measured by the Panorama Survey in Spring of 2027.
goals.currentdata: Emotional Regulation continues to be the lowest area on the Panorama Survey as illustrated below with a 65% positive response rate. 2025 Spring Student Panorama Data (Grades 3 – 5): 2025 Student SEL Competency and Well-Being Measures: • Challenging Feelings: 69% • Emotional Regulation: 65% • Positive Feelings: 71% • Self-Efficacy: 68% • Self-Management: 84% • Social Awareness: 72% • Supportive Relationships: 89% 2025 Student SEL Supports and Environment: • School Safety: 80% • Teacher-Student Relationships: 76% • Sense of Belonging: 69% Although we have made progress in the area of Emotional Regulation, as outlined in the sub-questions below, we have not yet reached our overall goal of 75% of students responding favorably. Sub-questions within Emotional Regulation: How often are you able to pull yourself out of a bad mood? • 2024: 55% favorable • 2025: 62% favorable (+7%) When things go wrong for you, how calm are you able to stay? • 2024: 49% favorable • 2025: 63% favorable (+14%) Once you get upset, how often can you get yourself to relax?

goals.strategies_summarized: Christa McAuliffe Elementary will implement a comprehensive, school-wide approach to emotional regulation instruction and support across all grade levels, with teachers in grades K-5 utilizing evidence-based curricula including Purposeful People and Second Steps lessons that directly address emotional regulation skills such as relaxation and calmness. Classroom teachers will employ multiple strategies including breathing techniques, sensory tools, "Calm Down" corners, movement breaks, and explicit instruction on vocabulary from the Panorama survey, while school counselors will teach "Zones of Regulation" and provide small group interventions and parent communication about home-based strategies. Additionally, all staff—including classified personnel—will receive professional development on de-escalation strategies, Kelso's Choices, and common language for supporting emotional regulation, with visual supports and resources placed throughout the school and included in the family handbook to ensure consistent implementation across all school settings.

goals.strategies_summarized: To achieve 85% or more of kindergarten and 1st grade students demonstrating proficiency in phonemic awareness by Spring 2028, Margaret Mead Elementary School will implement a comprehensive, multi-tiered approach centered on explicit phonemic awareness instruction. The school will implement whole-class Heggerty instruction daily (10-15 minutes) in collaboration with the Safety Net teacher, utilize explicit phonics lesson sequences during Wonders whole group instruction visible through administrative observations, and provide differentiated small group instruction using Wonders curricular tools for all students, particularly those with risk indicators. Additionally, qualifying students will receive targeted support through Safety Net (using SIPPS, UFLI, and Wonder Works) and multilingual support services, while teachers will continuously monitor FastBridge assessment data (BOY, MOY, and EOY) to determine instructional needs and adjust instruction accordingly.

goals.strategies_summarized: Margaret Mead Elementary School will achieve its mathematics proficiency goal by implementing a comprehensive, data-driven approach across grades 3-5. The school will review spring 2025 SBA and FastBridge assessment data to identify students below standard and monitor their growth throughout the year, with grade level teams and special education teachers coordinating instruction through daily intervention blocks and small group instruction. Teachers in grades K-5 will participate in horizontal and vertical teaming through the LEAP program to master the math curriculum and ensure students receive exposure to critical spring units before the SBA, while administration establishes clear expectations for curricular systems and provides instructional aide support during intervention blocks. Additionally, grade level teams will communicate regularly with families about curriculum to support learning at home, creating a unified system of assessment, instruction, and collaboration designed to bring 85% of students to proficiency by Spring 2028.

goals.strategies_summarized: Margaret Mead Elementary School will analyze grades 3-5 Panorama Survey data to identify emotional regulation needs and disseminate findings to raise staff awareness. The school will implement the Purposeful People program schoolwide as part of PBIS and MTSS initiatives, highlighting emotional regulation lessons and reviving the trait of the month communication, while simultaneously establishing a PBIS positive affirmation system across classrooms and the building to reinforce positive behavior choices. Additionally, the school will establish calm down corners in each classroom with explicit instruction on their use, incorporate mindfulness technology tools such as GoNoodle and Cosmic Kids Yoga, and explore purchasing the Purposeful People Tier 2 curriculum to support counselor lessons and special education intervention groups.

goals.raw_strategies: Action Professional Learning: Provide new staff training on CORE Reading Fundamentals and ongoing professional learning focused on phonemic awareness, phonics, and foundational reading practices. Provide ongoing professional learning focused on Visible Learning practices, professional learning communities, equity, and curriculum integration to ensure coherence across instructional areas and strengthen collective efficacy. Instructional Design & Implementation: Ensure daily 10–15 minute blocks for Heggerty and/or phonics instruction in all K–3 classrooms. Use Safety Net staff to support UFLI implementation through small-group instruction, co-teaching, and planning collaboration. Tiered Systems of Support: Develop and implement consistent Tier 1 reading practices across grade levels, ensuring early literacy instruction is systematic and explicit for all learners. Fidelity & Alignment: Conduct fidelity checks of Tier 1 practices to monitor implementation quality and maintain alignment with schoolwide reading goals.
goals.strategies_summarized: John Muir Elementary School will implement a comprehensive literacy initiative centered on the University of Florida Literacy Institute curriculum through multiple coordinated strategies, including professional learning for staff on CORE Reading Fundamentals, Visible Learning practices, and phonemic awareness, as well as daily 10-15 minute instructional blocks for Heggerty and phonics in all K-3 classrooms supported by Safety Net staff. The school will establish consistent, systematic, and explicit Tier 1 reading practices across grade levels and conduct regular fidelity checks to ensure implementation quality and alignment with schoolwide reading goals, thereby supporting proficiency for all students, including those receiving multilingual and special education services.

goals.outcome: By Spring 2026, students in grades K-5, will improve by at least one proficiency level or maintain grade-level proficiency in Numbers and Operations, measured by grade-level Common District Summative Assessments.
goals.raw_strategies: Action Professional Learning: Provide ongoing coaching and training on Building Thinking Classrooms strategies and Adaptation Packs to strengthen instructional practice. Offer DreamBox refreshers to reinforce conceptual understanding of place value. Provide ongoing professional learning focused on Visible Learning practices, professional learning communities, equity, and curriculum integration to ensure coherence across instructional areas and strengthen collective efficacy. Instructional Design & Implementation: Implement math small groups and Illustrative Mathematics (IM) Centers to promote student discourse, problem-solving, and differentiation. Ensure dedicated small-group math time is built into the master schedule. Tiered Systems of Support: Develop and implement consistent Tier 1 math practices across all classrooms, ensuring equitable access to high-quality instruction for all students. Fidelity & Alignment: Conduct fidelity checks of Tier 1 math practices and engage in cycles of inquiry focused on place value to support vertical alignment of standards across grade levels.
goals.strategies_summarized: John Muir Elementary School will strengthen instructional practices through ongoing professional learning on Building Thinking Classrooms strategies, DreamBox refreshers, Visible Learning practices, and professional learning communities to support teacher efficacy and coherence across grade levels. The school will implement math small groups and Illustrative Mathematics Centers with dedicated scheduling to promote student discourse and differentiation, while establishing consistent Tier 1 math practices across all classrooms to ensure equitable access to high-quality instruction. Additionally, the school will conduct regular fidelity checks and engage in cycles of inquiry focused on place value and vertical alignment to monitor implementation and support continuous improvement in Numbers and Operations proficiency.

goals.outcome: By June 2028, the percentage of students in grades 3–5 who demonstrate emotional regulation will increase from 46% to 54%, as measured by schoolwide SEL data from Panorama.
goals.currentdata: In the Spring of 2025 Panorama Survey Data, 46% of students responded favorably to questions in the area of Emotional Regulation. This is below the Lake Washington School District average of 50%.
goals.raw_strategies: Action Professional Learning: Provide staff training on the Zones of Regulation curriculum to build shared language, routines, and implementation expectations. Include instructional assistants and paraprofessionals to ensure consistent support practices across all settings. Provide ongoing professional learning focused on Visible Learning practices,professional learning communities and equity. Instructional Design & Implementation: Pilot the Zones of Regulation with a small teacher team to refine strategies before full schoolwide rollout. Introduce common SEL routines, visuals, and vocabulary to establish consistency throughout the building. Tiered Systems of Support: Implement Tier 2 social–emotional groups focused on emotional regulation, use Check-In/Check-Out systems for monitoring and connection, and apply the 10×10 system to proactively support student well-being. Fidelity & Environment: Create Zones-aligned learning environments and conduct fidelity checks to ensure consistent, high-quality SEL implementation.
goals.strategies_summarized: John Muir Elementary School will implement a comprehensive, tiered approach to improve emotional regulation by providing intensive professional learning on the Zones of Regulation curriculum to all staff, piloting the program with select teachers before full rollout, and establishing consistent SEL routines and vocabulary schoolwide. The school will support this implementation through tiered systems including Tier 2 emotional regulation groups, Check-In/Check-Out monitoring systems, and the 10×10 proactive support framework, while simultaneously creating Zones-aligned learning environments and conducting fidelity checks to ensure consistent, high-quality implementation across all settings. These coordinated efforts in staff training, instructional design, systems support, and environmental alignment will work together to increase the percentage of students in grades 3–5 demonstrating emotional regulation from 46% to 54% by June 2028.

goals.strategies_summarized: Redmond Elementary will implement a comprehensive, tiered approach to build students' emotional regulation and reduce externalizing behaviors by establishing schoolwide use of evidence-based SEL curricula (Second Step and Zones of Regulation), strengthening their Tier 1 PBIS system, and developing targeted Tier 2 and Tier 3 supports with ongoing progress monitoring through multiple data sources including the BEISY Survey, Panorama assessments, TFI data, and weekly tracking documentation. Staff will receive tiered SEL coaching from Dr. Tovah Shotland to support implementation, while enrichment experiences such as Flight School and SOAR will be offered monthly to reinforce positive behaviors and emotional skills development. Through this multi-layered approach combining universal instruction, targeted interventions, and coaching support, the school aims to move from 30% to 20% of students demonstrating multiple externalizing behaviors and increase emotional regulation skills from 50% to 80% across grade levels.

goals.focus_area: Implementation of UFLI instructional practices and materials to support our students in the areas of Phonics and Fluency.
goals.outcome: All students will meet literacy benchmarks by spring of 2026 as measured by Fastbridge in the areas that measure phonemic awareness, phonics and fluency.
goals.currentdata: • Kindergarten: Fall 48% → Spring 63% at/above benchmark • 1st Grade: Fall 61% → Spring 72% • 2nd Grade: Fall 54% → Spring 68% Across K–2, progress monitoring indicates slower growth in phonics automaticity and oral reading fluency, especially for developing readers and multilingual learners.
goals.raw_strategies: Action • All K–2 teachers, IAs, SN Teacher, and Instructional Coach complete UFLI training • All Kinder–2nd teachers and IAs complete one full UFLI coaching cycle • Monthly UFLI fidelity checks focusing on core routines, pacing, and lesson structure • Analyze progress-monitoring data every 6 weeks and adjust instructional groups • Deliver daily UFLI-aligned phonics instruction with pacing fidelity Measure of Fidelity of Implementation • PD attendance logs; certificates of completion • Coaching cycle notes and observation feedback • Walkthrough tool data logged monthly • PLC agendas; updated WIN/intervention rosters • Lesson plans; walkthrough evidence of UFLI routine consistency • Admin & Coach classroom walkthroughs • Intervention group progress-monitoring logs
goals.strategies_summarized: Norman Rockwell Elementary School will implement a comprehensive UFLI (Unified Foundational Literacy Instruction) training program for all K-2 teachers, instructional assistants, special needs teachers, and instructional coaches, followed by a complete coaching cycle to ensure effective delivery of daily, phonics-aligned instruction with fidelity. The school will conduct monthly fidelity checks focusing on core routines, pacing, and lesson structure, while analyzing progress-monitoring data every six weeks to adjust instructional groups accordingly. Fidelity will be monitored through professional development attendance logs, coaching cycle notes, walkthrough tool data, lesson plans, and intervention group progress-monitoring logs to ensure consistent implementation and student achievement of literacy benchmarks in phonemic awareness, phonics, and fluency.

goals.raw_strategies: Action • Weekly Number Talks implemented across all grade levels • Common assessments every 4–6 weeks to monitor priority standards • PD on math discourse structures and enVision problem-solving routines • WIN Block small-group intervention for targeted students • Use FastBridge Automaticity and CBM data to guide fluency instruction Measure of Fidelity of Implementation • Walkthrough data; teacher reflections • PLC agendas and common assessment logs • PD attendance; coaching notes • WIN schedules; intervention rosters • PM logs; instructional planning documents
goals.strategies_summarized: Norman Rockwell Elementary School will implement weekly Number Talks across all grade levels, administer common assessments every 4–6 weeks to monitor priority standards, and provide professional development on math discourse structures and enVision problem-solving routines to build teacher capacity. Additionally, the school will establish a WIN Block for small-group intervention targeting students below benchmark and use FastBridge Automaticity and CBM data to guide fluency instruction. Fidelity of implementation will be monitored through walkthrough data, teacher reflections, PLC agendas, common assessment logs, PD attendance, coaching notes, WIN schedules, intervention rosters, and instructional planning documents to ensure all students in grades 3–5 achieve measurable growth and narrow the achievement gap by 15%.

goals.strategies_summarized: Norman Rockwell Elementary School will implement a comprehensive social-emotional learning (SEL) program that includes counselor-led lessons on emotional regulation strategies (Zones, Kelso, problem-solving), small-group and targeted counseling for students in grades K-5, and daily SEL routines such as Second Step Digital, circles, and calming strategies embedded in classroom instruction. The school will also train classified staff on co-regulation and de-escalation techniques, establish consistent calming spaces in every classroom, provide monthly Beagle Buddies recess helper training, and utilize Check-In/Check-Out and Check & Connect protocols for students needing additional behavioral support. Fidelity will be monitored through scheduled lesson delivery verification, counselor attendance and progress note documentation, monthly environmental checks, SEL block scheduling confirmation, training attendance logs, and CICO/Check & Connect tracking to ensure these interventions effectively reduce physical aggression referrals by spring.

goals.outcome: 70% of students will show typical or aggressive growth from Fall to Spring as measured by the FastBridge Mathematics screener by Spring 2026.
goals.currentdata: Data: In the period from Fall 2022-Spring 2023, the mean by grade for students measuring typical or aggressive growth for the school was 57%. Typical growth is defined as falling in the 40th to 75th percentile, and aggressive growth is defined as 75th percentile or higher based on FastBridge. This measure is produced by the Group Growth Report, measuring Fall to Spring, based on comparing students’ median growth rate to median growth rate of students in the same grade nationally who started at the same score. Update: In the Fall 2023-Spring 2024 period, the mean by grade for students measuring typical or aggressive growth for the school was 55%. Update in Fall 2024-Spring 2025, the mean by grade for students measuring typical or aggressive growth for the school was 52%. We are struggling with this goal. While the achievement rate on FastBridge for our school remains high with 85% of students meeting or exceeding expected scores on the assessment, growth with this tool is a challenge. It’s important to note that Classroom-based measures show higher growth. There is some doubt in the FastBridge measurement tool among staff. Rationale: We want all students to grow in their learning. By measuring growth rate, we can monitor the progress of both students who are already achieving at high levels and need challenge as well as students who need support and intervention to meet benchmarks ensuring that students are making personal

goals.strategies_summarized: Rosa Parks Elementary will implement a comprehensive, multi-tiered mathematics support system to achieve 70% typical or aggressive growth by Spring 2026. All students will receive core mathematics instruction in their general education classroom with additional Special Education services for qualifying students, supplemented by Tier II interventions delivered through dedicated intervention block time and small group instruction. Teachers will utilize pre-assessments to identify student needs before each unit, employ "cool downs" for formative assessment and targeted feedback, leverage IM center activities and Dreambox adaptive software for practice and engagement, and structure small group learning to address specific skill gaps. Professional Learning Communities will guide teachers through cycles of inquiry focused on UDL strategies, access points for differentiating complexity, and collaboration between general and special education teachers to ensure all students, particularly those accessing special education services, have opportunities for growth.
goals.engagement_strategies: In their classroom newsletters, teachers will share math learning targets for each Illustrative Mathematics (IM) Unit, the family connection letter for each unit, as well as send strategies and resources to support math learning at home. They will also engage families through twice-a-year conferences and individual communications with families as needed. Schoolwide communications will occur through the weekly Puma Press newsletter, an annual family feedback survey, and well as parent participation on school committees (Equity, Safety, Special Education Advisory, etc…). We also work closely and collaboratively with our PTSA. Increased communication about student goals and student growth progress.

goals.outcome: 75% of students will show typical or aggressive growth from Fall to Spring as measured by the FastBridge Reading screener Group Growth Report by Spring 2026.
goals.currentdata: Data: In the period from Fall 2022-Spring 2023, the mean by grade level for students measuring typical or aggressive growth for the school was 67%. Typical growth is defined as falling in the 40th to 75th percentile and aggressive growth is defined as 75th percentile or higher on FastBridge. This measure is produced by the Group Growth Report, measuring Fall to Spring, based on comparing student’s median growth rate to median growth rate of students in the same grade nationally who started at the same score. Update: In the Fall 2023-Spring 2024 period, the mean by grade for students measuring typical or aggressive growth for the school was 54%. Update: In the Fall 2024-Spring 2025 period, the mean by grade for students measuring typical or aggressive growth for the school was 56%. We are struggling with this goal. While the achievement rate on FastBridge for our school remains high with 87% of students meeting or exceeding expected scores on the assessment, growth with this tool is a challenge. We’ve made small progress since last year. It’s important to note that Classroom-based measures show higher growth. There is some doubt about the FastBridge measurement tool among staff. Rationale: We want all students to grow in their learning. By measuring growth rate, we can monitor the progress of both students who are already achieving at high levels and need challenge as well as students who need support and intervention to meet benchmarks ensuring that students are making personal progress in their learning wherever they begin on the continuum. A growth measure is an important indicator of meeting the needs of all students. We are a high achieving school, and most students are meeting expected standards, but we want them to make a year’s growth even if they are already at standard.

goals.strategies_summarized: Rosa Parks Elementary will implement a comprehensive, multi-tiered reading intervention system to achieve this growth goal, beginning with daily differentiated small group instruction in every classroom targeting foundational skills gaps identified through FastBridge and classroom-based data. All K-2 students will receive systematic phonemic awareness and phonics instruction using the Heggerty and UFli curricula with support from Safety Net Teachers, while grades 3-5 students needing intervention will use Bridge the Gap resources, with progress monitored continuously through curriculum-based measures and FastBridge reports. Additionally, teachers will engage in professional learning communities and targeted professional development on intervention strategies and Universal Design for Learning, instructional assistants will provide supplemental support, and students will access Lexia adaptive software to reinforce reading skills, all while the master schedule ensures protected time for both whole group and small group reading instruction.

goals.outcome: 78% of all students will be able to regulate their emotions according to self-perception data as recorded by the Panorama survey data (grades 3-5) and through teacher data from the BEISY screener (K-5) by Spring 2026.
goals.currentdata: At the beginning of the 2022-2023 school year, 52% of students responded favorably on the Panorama survey when prompted to rate their ability to regulate their emotions. This overall percentage is lower than the beginning of the 2018-2019 school year at 54%. With focused, strategic, and school-wide instruction, we believe we can significantly increase students’ abilities to self- regulate their emotions. 2023-2024 update: In Spring 2024, 58% of students who took the Panorama survey responded favorably when prompted to rate their ability to regulate their emotions. Fall 2024 BEISY data: On the BEISY screener, teachers indicated 15% of students at risk for Externalizing Behaviors and 10% at risk for internalizing behaviors, suggesting 85% and 90% respectively are meeting SEL expectations.

goals.strategies_summarized: Rosa Parks Elementary will implement a comprehensive, school-wide approach to emotion regulation by adopting the Zones of Regulation framework across all classrooms, establishing calming corners with tools, and providing targeted interventions through student support teams and motor lab sessions for students needing additional support. The school will reinforce these skills through multiple integrated strategies including Character Strong curriculum implementation, explicit teaching of PUMAS expectations with videos and modeling, counselor-led lessons on self-regulation and social skills, universal SEL visuals in classrooms, and consistent teacher modeling with positive reinforcement of self-regulation strategies. Additionally, professional development for instructional assistants, a kindergarten-focused professional learning cycle targeting early skill-building, specialist-led closure activities aligned with PUMAS expectations, and partnerships with the school librarian to incorporate SEL-focused literature will create a cohesive system supporting student emotional regulation across all grade levels and settings.
goals.engagement_strategies: Teachers and counselor will communicate what Character Strong and SEL Skills are being taught in class lessons. Teachers and the school will communicate about goals and challenges in newsletters to families, seeking volunteers for recess and classroom support, etc. They will also engage families through twice-a-year conferences and individual communications with families as needed. Schoolwide communications will occur through the weekly Puma Press newsletter, an annual family feedback survey, and well as parent participation on school committees (Equity, Safety, Special Education Advisory, etc…). We also work closely and collaboratively with our PTSA.

goals.strategies_summarized: Rose Hill Elementary will implement a comprehensive social-emotional learning initiative to improve students' emotional regulation and sense of belonging. The school will encourage the use of MindYeti videos through Second Step while teaching explicit self-regulation language and strategies using the "Get to Green" Regulation Strategy sheet, monitored through both Second Step admin access and classroom implementation. Additionally, the Counseling Department will survey students to identify individual triggers and coping skills, analyze Panorama data to identify students with low scores, and share findings with staff, while also delivering targeted SEL units on Bounce Back/Resiliency and Mental Wellness from January through March to support students in managing challenging emotions and building stronger connections to school.

goals.strategies_summarized: Benjamin Rush Elementary School will implement a comprehensive, multi-tiered literacy approach to ensure all students achieve one year of growth in reading as measured by FastBridge data. The school will provide Tier 1 foundational instruction through daily Heggerty phonemic awareness activities in kindergarten through 2nd grade, explicit phonics instruction using the Wonders curriculum, and UFLi whole-group instruction in kindergarten, supported by professional learning for K-2 teachers. Additionally, the school will implement differentiated small-group instruction through Tier 2 interventions using the UFLi curriculum in collaboration with Safety Net and Multilingual Learner programs, as well as Tier 2-3 specialized instruction through the Special Education Program, ensuring that students with risk indicators and identified special needs receive targeted support in reading.

Additionally, the school will provide targeted small group differentiated instruction in regular classrooms and through the Special Education Program for students with identified reading needs. goals.strategies_summarized: Benjamin Rush Elementary School will implement a multi-tiered approach to increase peer connections and reduce the percentage of students without a trusted school friend. At Tier 1, teachers will implement the "4 at the door" strategy from Purposeful People to build connections school-wide, while Tier 2 interventions will include interviewing identified students with low peer connection to understand their needs and providing optional alternative recess activities focused on connecting students with similar interests. For students requiring additional support, Tier 3 will employ the 2x10 Relation Building strategy to strengthen connections between identified students and school staff. Progress will be monitored through collection of street data from student interviews in winter and spring, tracking participation in social groups, documenting the number of teachers implementing the "4 at the door" strategy, and recording the number of students who participate in the 2x10 intervention.

goals.outcome: 90% or more of Kindergarten, 1st , 2nd and 3rd grade students will demonstrate minimal to low risk in all components as measured by FastBridge reading on the Screening-to-Intervention (s2i) Report by Spring of 2026.
goals.currentdata: Preventing any student in grades K-2 from demonstrating high risk on the FastBridge End of Year assessments allows for early identification and targeted intervention. This proactive approach helps address reading difficulties before they become more entrenched, reducing long-term learning gaps. Monitoring growth through the Screening to Intervention Report ensures that instruction is responsive and tailored to each student’s needs, promoting equitable learning opportunities.

goals.strategies_summarized: Carl Sandburg Elementary School will implement a comprehensive, multi-tiered literacy approach to achieve this goal, beginning with whole-class Heggerty phonemic awareness instruction in Kindergarten through 2nd grade for 10-15 minutes daily with collaborative support from Safety Net teachers. Teachers will incorporate explicit phonics and phonemic awareness instruction during all Wonders whole-group lessons, monitored through administrative observations, while simultaneously providing Tier 2 small-group, differentiated instruction for students showing risk indicators in phonemic awareness using Wonders curricular tools and in phonics and fluency using FastBridge intervention plans with individual student progress monitoring. Additionally, the school will implement small-group instruction using the UFLI curriculum, with documented group rosters and lesson plans to ensure all at-risk students in grades K-3 receive targeted support to meet the FastBridge reading screening benchmarks by Spring 2026.

goals.outcome: Students in grade 5 will grow by a median growth percentile of 60 or greater on the Spring 2026 ELA SBA.
goals.currentdata: When students get to middle school, there is a huge shift to reading to learn, versus learning to read. Our current data shows that students grew by a median growth percentile of 51 on the Spring 2025 ELA SBA, 49 on the Spring 2024 ELA SBA and 57on the Spring 2023 ELA SBA. This means that just about half of our students are growing less than their peers of the same age with similar score profiles throughout the state. This same data trend is also evident in FastBridge Growth Percentile data from the 2024- 2025 school year.

goals.strategies_summarized: Carl Sandburg Elementary School will review growth data in FastBridge during winter to identify student strengths and weaknesses, then update their watch list with current data to ensure they are addressing the most pressing student needs. The school will implement flexible small groups during WINN 1 and WINN 2 periods based on individual student needs, utilizing resources such as guided practices, modeling, graphic organizers, and multi-sensory instruction to support growth. Additionally, the school will provide clear success criteria for assignments and leverage peer tutoring, collaboration with same-level peers, and personalized engagement strategies to help fifth-grade students achieve a median growth percentile of 60 or greater on the Spring 2026 ELA SBA.

goals.strategies_summarized: Samantha Smith Elementary School will implement a comprehensive, multi-tiered literacy approach to achieve 95% grade-level proficiency by Spring 2026. The school will deliver explicit, systematic Tier 1 instruction using evidence-based programs (Wonders, UFLI, and Heggerty), while leveraging FastBridge screening data to identify at-risk students and provide targeted Tier 2 small-group interventions supported by consistent Lexia Core5 usage and maintained IA schedules. To ensure continuous improvement, the school will dedicate staff time to data analysis through regular MTSS Leadership and Intervention Team meetings, progress monitoring for students not on track, and professional learning opportunities focused on structured literacy—all documented through classroom observations, intervention logs, and data review meeting notes to track growth and adjust supports as needed.
goals.engagement_strategies: • Share 2025–26 SIP goals and priorities with the PTSA Board and at a general membership meeting. • Post a family-friendly summary of SIP goals and KPI alignment on ParentSquare and the school website. • Include updates and celebrations related to SIP goals and classroom learning in Principal newsletter to families. • Provide families with grade-level information on literacy and math expectations through newsletters and classroom communication. • Encourage student reflection on learning progress and goal setting during conferences and classroom celebrations. • Gather family feedback through annual surveys and informal listening sessions to guide next steps in school improvement.

goals.strategies_summarized: Samantha Smith Elementary School will implement a comprehensive, multi-tiered approach to mathematics instruction centered on delivering Illustrative Math with fidelity while incorporating Building Thinking Classrooms strategies to enhance engagement and mathematical reasoning across all K–5 classrooms. Teachers will engage in regular collaboration through dedicated LEAP and staff meeting time focused on lesson planning and data analysis, supported by district math facilitators who will provide instructional coaching to strengthen Tier 1 instruction. For students identified as at-risk through FastBridge assessments and classroom formative assessments, the school will implement targeted Tier 2 interventions coordinated through the MTSS-I process, utilizing strategically deployed instructional assistant support for small-group instruction and integrating adaptive math tools such as DreamBox for individualized practice, while the MTSS Leadership Team and Intervention Team monitor progress and celebrate student growth through regular data reflection cycles.

goals.strategies_summarized: Samantha Smith Elementary School will implement a comprehensive, multi-tiered approach to teach students self-regulation strategies aligned with the Zones of Regulation framework. Universal instruction will be delivered through core Zones of Regulation lessons and Purposeful People lessons taught by classroom teachers, supported by school counselor lessons in general education classrooms, with all classrooms equipped with emotional regulation spaces and tools as verified through classroom walk-throughs. For students requiring additional support, the school will provide targeted small group instruction based on screening data, LINKS mentorships, individual Check-In and Check-Out systems, and monitoring of students with no self-identified strengths through the Tier 2 interventions process, with the PBIS & SEL work team and MTSS Leadership and Intervention Teams coordinating building-wide efforts and supporting at-risk students.

Historically, over the last two years, about 65% of students below grade level have made one year or more growth and our goal is to increase growth in this subgroup to impact overall proficiency.

goals.strategies_summarized: Thoreau Elementary will achieve this outcome through a multifaceted approach centered on building strong relationships with families, providing high-quality culturally responsive instruction, and implementing targeted small group intervention. Teachers will establish connections with families to inform personalized student growth goals focused on literacy, while simultaneously creating community-building opportunities such as summer library hours, book fairs, and reading nights to foster family engagement and volunteering in classrooms. Additionally, professional learning communities will engage in continuous cycles of inquiry and unit planning focused on literacy instruction, and flexible small group instruction will be implemented daily with dedicated IA support in grades K-2 using evidence-based UFLI practices, with progress monitored through teacher data tracking and reflection.

goals.currentdata: Our ML student population is lower in proficiency than any other subgroup of students. On the WSIF, ML students at Thoreau are in the 2nd decile for achievement which is well below our goal of the 5th decile or above. We continue to see low growth in reading on standardized tests including FastBridge and SBA for ML students. Our street data indicates that ML students enjoy project-based learning, presentations on topics of their choice, and partner work in the classroom. We hope to capitalize on ML student assets in our instruction this year to increase rigor and engagement leading to an increase in growth and proficiency.

goals.focus_area: Reading proficiency across grade levels is part of a broader focus on academic achievement and instructional effectiveness in literacy, tied to LWSD priorities.
goals.outcome: By June 2025, each grade level at Mark Twain Elementary will demonstrate measurable growth in reading proficiency, as evidenced by EarlyReading (K–1) and AReading (grades 2–5) benchmark assessments. Specifically: • Grades currently below 80% proficiency (K: 75%, 1st: 79%, 2nd: 66%, 3rd: 75%, 5th: 69%) will show a minimum 10 percentage point increase in the percentage of students meeting or exceeding grade- level benchmarks. • Grades already above 80% proficiency (4th:90%) will maintain or improve their performance, ensuring continued excellence in reading achievement. This outcome reflects the school’s commitment to equitable academic growth, targeted support, and sustained high performance across all grade levels.

goals.strategies_summarized: To achieve measurable growth in reading proficiency across all grade levels by June 2025, Mark Twain Elementary will implement a comprehensive, multi-tiered approach centered on maximizing instructional time and providing targeted support. The school will establish uninterrupted blocks of dedicated Tier 1 reading instruction in every classroom while delivering consistent Tier 2 instruction within the general education setting four times per week for students below benchmark, supplemented by intensive small-group Tier 2 and 3 interventions of 30 minutes four times per week for those requiring additional support. Through weekly collaborative planning, grade-level teams will ensure all students receive high-quality core instruction without unnecessary pull-outs (except as specified in IEPs), while multilingual learners receive integrated language development support through co-teaching and co-planning with ML specialists. Progress will be monitored using consistent benchmark assessments every six weeks, with more frequent monitoring every two weeks for students not meeting expectations, allowing teams to analyze data and adjust instruction every 6–8 weeks to ensure continued growth and sustained excellence across all grade levels.
goals.engagement_strategies: This year is a learning year as we focus on developing and refining our Strategy to Engage Students, Families, Parents, and Community Members. Our goal is to explore best practices, gather feedback, and build strong partnerships that support student success. We recognize that meaningful engagement takes time and collaboration, and we are committed to learning and improving together throughout this process.

goals.focus_area: Math proficiency across grade levels is part of a broader focus on academic achievement and instructional effectiveness in math tied to LWSD priorities of equitable access and closing achievement gaps.
goals.outcome: By June 2025, Mark Twain Elementary will increase math proficiency across all grade levels as measured by EarlyMath (K–1) and aMath (grades 2–5) benchmark assessments. Specifically: • Grades below 80% proficiency (Second: 69%, Third: 73%, Fifth: 78%) will show a minimum 10 percentage point increase in the percentage of students meeting or exceeding grade-level benchmarks. • Grades at or above 80% proficiency (Kindergarten: 86%, First: 88%, Fourth: 82%) will maintain or improve their performance to ensure sustained excellence in math achievement.

goals.strategies_summarized: Mark Twain Elementary will implement a comprehensive, multi-faceted approach to increase math proficiency across all grade levels by June 2025. The school will establish protected, uninterrupted blocks of Tier 1 math instruction in every classroom while delivering consistent Tier 2 interventions four times weekly for students not meeting benchmarks, with particular focus on foundational skills in grades 2–3 where proficiency gaps are largest. Teachers will engage in weekly interdisciplinary collaboration during common planning to ensure all students receive high-quality core instruction without unnecessary pull-outs, supported by ongoing professional development including coaching from the instructional coach and training in evidence-based strategies such as Building Thinking Classrooms. Progress will be monitored consistently using FastBridge assessments in fall, winter, and spring, with fidelity checks through informal walk-throughs to ensure the schedule and interventions are being implemented with integrity.

goals.outcome: By June 2025, Mark Twain Elementary will strengthen staff- student relationships to meet or exceed district averages as measured by Panorama surveys. Specifically, we will increase student confidence that staff care when they are upset and by at least 10 percentage points and reverse the 11% decline since 2021. Additionally, we will increase how difficult it is to find help from an adult if a student is bullied by at least 10 percentage points.

goals.strategies_summarized: Mark Twain Elementary will strengthen staff-student relationships and reduce bullying through increased adult visibility and responsiveness, enhanced staff training, and targeted social-emotional support. Classified staff will monitor high-risk areas throughout the day with weekly verification of presence and responsiveness, while all staff will receive training on immediate response protocols with weekly review of implementation. Additionally, the school will provide weekly SEL lessons focused on anti-bullying strategies and empathy-building, conduct quarterly student interviews to gather input on school climate, and implement Tier 2 interventions delivered by the school counselor for students identified through benchmark assessments and behavior data, with weekly administrative review of incident data and six- to eight-week data cycles to ensure responsive support and prompt adjustments based on student progress.

goals.focus_area: Grades PK-2 - Phonemic Awareness and Phonics Grades 3-5 – Reading Comprehension
goals.outcome: Preschool – 80% of students will demonstrate benchmark proficiency as measured by the Heggerty assessment in Spring 2026. K-2 – 85% of students will demonstrate benchmark proficiency in foundational reading skills as measured by the FastBridge screening assessment in Spring 2026. 3-5 – 90% of students will demonstrate benchmark proficiency in reading comprehension skills as measured by the FastBridge screening assessment in Spring 2026.
goals.currentdata: Preschool: Heggerty implementation will begin this year Kindergarten: Students at 82% proficiency on Fastbridge Fall 2025 screener. Grades 1-2: In Spring 2025, 74% of students met the benchmark standard for literacy in the earlyReading assessment. Grades 3-5: In Spring 2025, 83% of students met the benchmark standard for literacy in the aReading assessment. Research shows that through explicit phonemic awareness, phonics and fluency instruction, students develop strong foundational skills that lead them to becoming proficient readers. To achieve this, Wilder Elementary will utilize researched-based practices and curriculum resources to provide explicit phonemic awareness, phonics and fluency core instruction and interventions to help students grow and become strong readers. “Foundational skills…are necessary and important components of an effective comprehensive reading program designed to develop proficient readers with capacity to comprehend texts…” (Common Core State Standards, 2010). The National Reading Panel (2000) identified five essential components of reading instruction: phonological awareness, phonics, fluency, vocabulary,

goals.strategies_summarized: Laura Ingalls Wilder Elementary School will implement a comprehensive literacy initiative across preschool through fifth grade, beginning with professional development in comprehension strategies during LEAP time and the implementation of evidence-based phonics and phonemic awareness instruction through Heggerty (PK-2) and UFLI (K-2) programs, with yearly use reviews to ensure fidelity. Teachers will participate in Professional Learning Communities to analyze student progress using informal and formal assessments and adjust instruction accordingly, while the school's master schedule dedicates core instructional time and power blocks to provide differentiated Tier 1, 2, and 3 instruction based on individual student needs. Additionally, staff will employ scaffolding and differentiation strategies through Universal Design for Learning (UDL) practices, with the MTSS Intervention Team conducting yearly reviews of academic instruction quality to monitor progress toward the benchmark proficiency goals across all grade levels.

goals.outcome: 85% of students in grades 3-5 will be at or above level 3 in Mathematics as measured by the Smarter Balanced Assessment in Spring of 2026.
goals.currentdata: Data analysis of our SBA scores from last year indicates that 20% of our students are at or below level 2. Students in grades 3-5 experience few complex problem-solving opportunities through regular classroom instruction which is primarily focused on a specific strategy for solving problems.

goals.strategies_summarized: Laura Ingalls Wilder Elementary School will implement a comprehensive, multi-layered approach to improve mathematics achievement by utilizing tiered instruction aligned with their MTSS framework, with dedicated core instructional time and power blocks for targeted student support. Teachers will collaborate in Professional Learning Communities to analyze student work from IM Units and formal/informal assessments, using data to inform instructional adjustments and maximize impact on student learning. To support the conditions necessary for academic success, the school will create a positive, supportive learning environment through the implementation of Universal Design for Learning practices with differentiation and scaffolding strategies, daily SEL/restorative circles, schoolwide PBIS programs, accessible regulation and sensory spaces, and targeted small group lessons on self-regulation and emotion regulation using the Zones of Regulation curriculum.

goals.outcome: 65% of students in grades 3-5 will respond favorably in the emotional regulation category as measured by the Panorama Survey in Spring 2026.
goals.currentdata: In the Spring of 2025 60% of students responded favorably on Emotion Regulation as measured by Panorama. Dr. Richie Davidson (University of Wisconsin-Madison) speaks about ‘every behavioral intervention being a biological intervention’—and that a young person’s repeated experiences in school have the opportunity to be a powerful influence for the re- wiring of neural pathways that is necessary for habits to be built and sustained. Implementing and sustaining a consistent set of SEL practices helps stakeholders collaboratively create the climate and culture that’s vital for optimal learning and working conditions for students and adults (CASEL, 2024). While SEL alone will not solve longstanding and deep-seated inequities in the education system, it can help schools promote understanding, examine biases, reflect on and address the impact of racism, build cross-cultural relationships, and cultivate adult and student practices that close opportunity gaps and create a more inclusive school community. In doing so, schools can promote high-quality educational opportunities and outcomes for all students, irrespective of race, socioeconomic status, gender, sexual orientation, and other differences. This requires that SEL is implemented with an explicit goal of promoting educational equity (CASEL, 2024).

strategies.action: MTSS Tier 2/3 Intervention Team will meet monthly and in response to student needs to develop agreed upon Tiered interventions that will support students inside and outside the classroom and monitor student progress.
strategies.measures: % of staff who implement strategies from MTSS Team.

goals.strategies_summarized: To achieve 65% of students in grades 3-5 responding favorably in the emotional regulation category on the Spring 2026 Panorama Survey, Laura Ingalls Wilder Elementary School will implement a comprehensive, multi-layered approach to social-emotional learning and student support. The school will establish a consistent schoolwide PBIS program through whole staff collaboration, implement daily SEL and restorative circles in all classrooms with ongoing professional development, and provide counselor-led small group and whole-group lessons using the Zones of Regulation curriculum, with progress monitored through pre/post assessments and discipline data. Additionally, the MTSS Tier 2/3 Intervention Team will meet monthly to develop and monitor tiered interventions for individual student needs, while all classrooms will utilize dedicated regulation spaces, sensory paths, and a sensory gym to support student emotional regulation throughout the school day.
goals.engagement_strategies: • Admin and counselor share SEL goals and information in family newsletter with regular updates about our school steps and ways families can support at home. • Connections conferences and mid-year conferences to connect, build relationships and share student progress and grade level expectations with families. • Regular follow-Up from counselor to share individual and group progress with families. • Parent connection night on Zones of Regulation with opportunities for practice and takeaways with students, staff and families. • Empathy interviews to build capacity and see our families and students through feedback opportunities around the SIP goals through video and audio recording. • Affinity groups for families of students (IEP, 504, ML and race) to connect with them and hear about their needs and concerns. • Increasing the use of phone or in person conversations versus email or parent square.

goals.strategies_summarized: The Environmental & Adventure School will implement a comprehensive literacy initiative to ensure all students achieve level 3 or higher on the SBA by the end of 8th grade. This multi-faceted approach begins with universal screening through FastBridge, where all students will complete the assessment and staff will collaboratively review results to identify areas of need. The school will strengthen writing instruction through common writing prompts developed across all classes for expeditions and school-wide activities, supported by regular collaboration among the humanities department to analyze student writing trends and refine formative and summative assessments. Additionally, a peer-to-peer tutoring club will provide targeted writing support to help students develop the literacy skills necessary to meet grade-level standards.

goals.outcome: All students will pass Algebra by the end of 8th grade
goals.currentdata: 6 of 47 students of the current 7th grade class and 9 of 48 students of the current 8th grade class did not earn standard on the previous year’s SBA

strategies.action: Department collaboration

goals.strategies_summarized: The Environmental & Adventure School will ensure all students pass Algebra by 8th grade through a multi-faceted approach that includes differentiated math instruction with foundational coursework, multiple acceleration pathways, and challenge problems to meet diverse student needs. The school will implement peer tutoring through student leadership teams and provide school-wide assessment retakes, while the EAS team meets weekly to discuss struggling students and share effective intervention strategies. Additionally, math department members will collaborate across grade levels to track student progress over three years and share successful teaching strategies to support continued improvement.

goals.focus_group: Family engagement with adventure and community service education
goals.focus_area: 6th, 7th, and 8th grade students and their families
goals.outcome: Students will extend their experiences from adventure education excursions and community stewardship projects to their families through journal prompts, written reflections, and guided family discussion questions.
goals.currentdata: Over the past several years, EAS has experienced a decrease in the number of families involved in supporting school activities by driving, chaperoning, or leading Wednesday Elective sessions and/or after-school clubs. Specifically with CSPs and Adventure Education trips, only a limited number of parents/guardians can attend. Because community stewardship and adventure education are pillars of EAS as a school, the EAS staff sought out additional ways to engage families in these critical components of our school. EAS staff agreed that sharing CSP and expedition journaling with families was not only a good jumping-off point for discussions at home, but also a way to amplify student voice in the discussion. The goal is to have… • 100% family participation in CSP Journal communication and Expedition Journal communication. • An increase in family involvement from the student’s 6th grade year to their 8th grade year

strategies.action: EAS staff collaboration
strategies.measures: Development, implementation, and assessment of common journal prompts

strategies.action: Student self-assessment
strategies.measures: Student reflection on CSP and expedition experiences

strategies.action: Family self-assessment
strategies.measures: Students and families reflect, discuss, and write about CSP and expedition experiences

strategies.action: Fall and winter conferences
strategies.measures: Students, families, and teachers engage in discussion of experiences at camp/CSP as well as the journaling process

goals.strategies_summarized: The Environmental & Adventure School will develop common journal prompts through staff collaboration that students will use to reflect on their adventure education excursions and community stewardship projects, fostering individual self-assessment of these experiences. Students and families will then engage in guided reflection, discussion, and written responses about these expedition and service learning experiences together. Additionally, fall and winter conferences will provide opportunities for students, families, and teachers to collectively discuss both the camp and community stewardship experiences and evaluate the journaling process itself, ensuring that learning extends meaningfully from school to home.
goals.engagement_strategies: • School-home communication via CSP and Expedition Journals • ParentSquare communication • Fall and winter conferences

goals.strategies_summarized: To achieve 85% of multilingual learners increasing their ELA achievement by one or more performance levels by Spring 2026, Evergreen Middle School will implement a comprehensive, multi-layered approach centered on instructional support and progress monitoring. The school will provide daily support for ML co-taught classes while equipping teachers with evidence-based ML strategies through professional development during LEAP sessions and regular ML teacher consultations. Additionally, the school will offer weekly FLEX sessions for targeted literacy support, implement frequent progress monitoring through classroom-based formative assessments and FastBridge, and prioritize collaborative planning time during grade level meetings and PLC teams to ensure all staff—including instructional assistants and paraprofessionals—are equipped to identify and implement Multi-Tiered Systems of Support (MTSS) interventions based on student literacy needs.

The school will prioritize Eagle Time for check-ins, social-emotional learning, and restorative practices twice weekly, and will gather student feedback through mid-year focus groups and surveys to adjust strategies based on student input. Progress will be monitored through intermittent student surveys and tracked during grade level team meetings and PLC teams, allowing teachers to share effective practices and ensure continuous improvement toward the outcome.

goals.strategies_summarized: To achieve literacy proficiency by 8th grade, Finn Hill Middle School will implement a comprehensive, multi-layered approach that combines professional development, targeted interventions, and continuous progress monitoring. The school will provide equitable grading practices through staff professional development, offer flex options and motivational interviewing to support struggling students, and deploy evidence-based literacy programs including Language Live, Lexia in co-taught classes, phonics programming for multilingual learners, and targeted reading support through IXL and after-school homework machine sessions. Progress will be continuously monitored through formative assessments including SBA Interim Assessments, FastBridge data, teacher observations, and IXL performance metrics, with summative achievement measured by the 2026 ELA SBA.

goals.strategies_summarized: Finn Hill Middle School will implement a comprehensive multi-faceted approach to ensure all students pass Algebra by the end of 8th grade, beginning with professional development for staff on equitable grading practices and utilizing flexible support options including review sessions, targeted check-ins, and motivational interviewing with counselors to provide personalized student support. The school will leverage evidence-based digital curricula including ALEKS, Imagine Learning, and Amplify Desmos, supported by formative assessments through FastBridge and ALEKS to monitor progress, while also offering targeted after-school math support through the Homework Machine on Tuesdays and Thursdays to address gaps in student learning. Success will be measured through adjustments to grading practices, monitoring of student participation in flex and teacher supports, updates on student progress through the "Students with Potential" spreadsheet, digital practice engagement, and ultimately, through the 2026 Math SBA summative assessment.

goals.strategies_summarized: To achieve a 13-percentage-point increase in favorable student responses on the Panorama Survey's Student-Teacher Relationships domain, Finn Hill Middle School will implement a comprehensive approach centered on strengthening teacher-student connections. This will include professional development for teachers on building positive relationships through empathy, active listening, and conflict resolution; regular one-on-one check-ins to discuss academic progress and personal concerns; collaborative learning activities that promote teamwork; positive reinforcement techniques targeting a 5:1 ratio of positive to negative interactions; and the creation of an inclusive classroom environment where all students feel valued. Additionally, FHMS will establish mentorship programs, promote extracurricular activities and Falcon Clubs that allow informal interactions around shared interests, implement Falcon Time lessons focused on relationship-building, and conduct administrator-teacher classroom observations centered on student growth goals to gather data and support improvements in student-teacher relationships.

goals.strategies_summarized: Inglewood Middle School will strategically place Resource Special Education students in appropriate math classes with specially designed instruction while implementing professional development for teachers on curriculum accommodations and modifications, supported by learning walks in co-taught Algebra classrooms that serve as demonstration models. Teachers will receive targeted professional development on algebraic thinking, the Hess Rigor Matrix, and culturally responsive teaching strategies, while participating in learning walks to observe and implement effective instructional practices such as building thinking classroom strategies. goals.outcome: By May 2026, students’ general academic self-efficacy scores on the Panorama Survey will increase by at least 5% from the 2025 results, as measured by the Self-Efficacy domain. Self-efficacy is the belief in one’s ability to succeed in specific situations or accomplish a task, significantly influencing motivation, behavior and personal achievement. It is essentially the confidence one has in their ability to influence events and control their environment. We want to provide our students with evidence that they have the ability to meet our high academic expectations.
goals.currentdata: Panorama Survey Data, Counselor Needs Assessment survey and Student Listening Session comments from 24-25 reveal this as a growth opportunity. Panorama: Trend Panorama survey data for the past years shows that we have not made the overall consistent positive progress that we have made in some of the other categories in recent years; such as supportive relationships, positive feelings, emotion regulation, social perspective taking. We started some professional development on self-efficacy in the 24-25 school year and did make significant (4% points) progress since the Fall 2024 survey. We want to build on this progress. Panorama data from Spring 2025 shows that this area continues to show the greatest gap with students who identify as Hispanic/Latino (of any race) and/or Black African American. These students combined self-report 25% less favorable self- efficacy as our other racial and ethnic groups. This area also contains the 3rd greatest disparity for our male and female students with our female students reporting a 9% less favorable response. Counselor Needs Assessment: In Fall of 2025, 49% of students that took the survey felt very confident that they could succeed in their schoolwork. The other

The school will also provide explicit, school-wide instruction in executive functioning skills during Cougar Time and Flex Planning Time, supported by teacher reflection through the Instructional Leadership Team, while simultaneously enhancing instructional quality through professional development on Danielson best practices, culturally responsive teaching with Dr. Stembridge and the Hess Rigor Matrix, and evaluation through Panorama surveys. goals.strategies_summarized: To achieve 100% of 8th grade classes demonstrating at or above proficiency in explanatory writing by Spring 2027, Kirkland Middle School will implement explicit instruction in thesis/claim writing, evidence selection and elaboration, paragraph/essay structure, and conclusion strategies, supported by progress monitoring and additional writing sessions for students needing support. Students will engage in structured peer feedback at least quarterly using taught rubric skills, while simultaneously developing self-assessment abilities through checklists, rubrics, and graphic organizers that encourage reflection on writing strengths and growth. Additionally, the school will extend these writing strategies across the curriculum by sharing common vocabulary, definitions, and rubrics with at least one other department, as evidenced through cross-departmental PLC meeting notes documenting plans for explanatory writing integration.

goals.outcome: On the Spring 2026 Math Smarter Balanced Assessment (SBA), 100% of 8th grade classes will demonstrate “above the proficiency standard” or “at/near the proficiency standard” on Target E: Define, Evaluate, and Compare Functions.
goals.currentdata: Spring 2025 SBA Results – Math Target E, Grade 8 Mathematics Grade 8 – Class of 2029 3 out of 12 classes scored “above the proficiency standard”, 4 classes scored “at/near the proficiency standard”, and 6 classes scored “below the proficiency standard”. As a grade level, our performance on this target as compared to others was identified as an “area of weakness”. Additionally, the following classes showed that target was an “area of weakness” compared to the other targets: • 2 classes that scored “above the proficiency standard”, • 3 classes that scored “at/near the proficiency standard”, and • 5 of the classes that scored “below the proficiency standard”. Additional rationale for this focus: Functions form the foundation of algebraic thinking and are central to success in Algebra I and will be utilized in subsequent math courses. Strengthening students’ ability to define, evaluate, and compare functions supports the transition from arithmetic and proportional reasoning to more abstract reasoning about relationships and quantities. It also supports students identifying the connections between equations, tables, graphs, and descriptions of functions – skills required for modeling real-world situations and data interpretation.

strategies.measures: • Team meeting notes throughout the year include lesson design around functions, formative assessment results, and student misconceptions around functions. • Common assessment questions and student work connected to functions are analyzed collaboratively for each unit functions are taught or reviewed. • Documentation includes sharing of effective instructional strategies, instructional adjustments made, and intervention strategies.

strategies.measures: • Unit plans and/or lesson plans show the integration of additional lessons and tasks on functions in relevant units. • Informal and/or formal observations confirm the use of supplemental lessons and/or tasks.

strategies.measures: • Lessons plans and informal and/or formal observations show multiple representations used to define, evaluate, and compare functions. • Student work displays evidence of learning tied to functions. • Informal and/or formal observations confirm the explicit teaching and/or reteaching of functions.

strategies.measures: • Lesson plans include at least one rich task in each relevant unit. • Informal and/or formal observations show opportunities for discussion, justification, and comparison of function behaviors. • PLC notes document discussion of rich tasks.

strategies.measures: • Rosters show students who qualify for Safety Net supports are enrolled in interventionist supported Algebra courses. • Math interventionists and core math teachers collaborate regularly. • Informal and formal observations confirm instruction focuses on conceptual understanding, skill development, and confidence and self-efficacy building strategies. • Informal and formal observations confirm instruction is delivered by both the core math teacher and the interventionist.

strategies.action: Offer and intentionally recruit students who qualify for Safety Net supports into a small math support class designed to complement their general education math course by pre-teaching and re- teaching concepts and skills while building self-efficacy and mathematical confidence.
strategies.measures: • Students and their families who were actively recruited into the class are enrolled. • The support class is scheduled concurrently with the students’ general education math course. • Lesson plans show alignment between support class content and core math class content. • The math interventionist and the math teacher engage in regular communication which is used to identify pre- teaching and re-teaching priorities. • Informal and/or formal observations confirm evidence of alignment between the support and core classes and focus on core understandings and concepts.

strategies.action: Implement a school-wide weekly math problem-solving challenge – Pounce on a Problem! – aligned to current content areas (Math 6+, Math 7+, and Algebra and Geometry). Algebra and Geometry challenge problems will intentionally include problems involving functions throughout the year.
strategies.measures: • Weekly challenge calendar and problem sets that include function-based problems at least once a month. • Student participation rates and work samples • Algebra and Geometry PLC discussions and/or meeting notes on student participation, accuracy in solving function problems, and common misconceptions.

strategies.action: Develop and implement a math focused peer mentoring program which delivers math instruction and support during Academic Prep
strategies.measures: • A peer mentoring cadre is recruited and trained. • Maintain a calendar of peer mentor assignments during AP. • Survey mentors quarterly about their mentoring experience and act accordingly.

goals.strategies_summarized: To achieve 100% of 8th grade classes demonstrating proficiency on functions by Spring 2026, Kirkland Middle School will implement a comprehensive, multi-faceted approach centered on collaborative planning, enhanced instruction, and targeted support. The Algebra I team will engage in ongoing data teaming and common assessment development focused on functions, while supplementing the current curriculum with additional lessons and tasks across the Functions, Linear Functions, Quadratic Functions, and Exponential Functions units—all taught using multiple representations (equations, tables, graphs, and function notation). To support all students, the school will offer Academic Prep sessions and a peer mentoring program throughout the year, strategically place Safety Net-eligible students in interventionist-supported Algebra classes, and provide a concurrent small math support class designed to pre-teach and re-teach concepts while building mathematical confidence. Additionally, the school will incorporate rich, real-world tasks that promote mathematical discourse, include function-based problems in the school-wide "Pounce on a Problem!" weekly challenge, and ensure that Geometry students review and practice defining, evaluating, and comparing functions throughout the year.
goals.engagement_strategies: 1) The school will communicate this SIP goal to all families via email and by posting this SIP on the school website. 2) During Principal Cassaro’s Ask Me Anything (AMA) quarterly meetings with families, this goal and progress toward this goal will be reviewed. 3) Teachers will send communications to families about coursework related to this goal, including a family-friendly explanation of what functions are and why they matter, short problems/examples, and conversation starters. 4) Create a bulletin board in the school called “Math in Real Life” highlighting how functions are used in the real world using high interest examples (e.g. local sports, gaming, local topics).

goals.outcome: Student reported self-efficacy will increase 6%, from 54% to 60% (as measured by the Panorama Survey of Student SEL Competency & Well-Being Measures).
goals.currentdata: Self-efficacy is one’s belief in their ability to complete specific tasks. These beliefs directly shape how students approach learning. When students believe they will be successful, they are willing to attempt challenging tasks, take intellectual risks, persist through difficulty, and recover from setbacks. When students have low self-efficacy, even students who are capable avoid rigorous work and give up quickly. By intentionally building student self-efficacy, we will teach and empower students to approach their learning with confidence, embrace rigor, and grow into resilient self-directed learners.

strategies.action: Self-efficacy lessons including mindset and skills will be embedded into Panther Time throughout the year.
strategies.measures: • Lesson slide decks are developed and scheduled by our Panther Time coordinator and provided to teachers.

strategies.action: Staff will learn about self- efficacy, including theory and skills/strategies for use of the classroom.
strategies.measures: • An average of 90% of KiMS staff participate in professional learning related to self-efficacy throughout the school year. • Follow-up surveys show at least 80% of staff can articulate key concepts and have identified at least 2 self-efficacy building strategies for use in their classrooms.

strategies.action: Teachers will incorporate self- efficacy practices into their instructional practice.
strategies.measures: • Informal and formal observation (or classroom walk-throughs) data show at least one self-efficacy strategy present in at least 80% of classrooms. • PLC and/or grade level logs document intentional use of self-efficacy strategies within lessons and/or units.

strategies.action: Students will complete monthly surveys (via Forms) on their perception of their own self-efficacy.
strategies.measures: • 90% of students complete each survey. • Survey data is reviewed by the Panther Time coordinator, the Principal and AP, and counselors within a week of the survey administration. • Adjustments to self-efficacy learning progression are made based on survey feedback. • Anonymous student survey data is shared with staff.

strategies.action: Individual self-efficacy check- ins for students meeting with their counselors, the dean, or an administrator during Student Success Meetings (SSM).
strategies.measures: • 100% of students scheduled for Student Success Meetings (SSM) participate in an individual self- efficacy check-in. • Notes from the SSM show consistent use of the Self- Efficacy protocol developed for these meetings.

goals.strategies_summarized: To achieve a 6% increase in student reported self-efficacy, Kirkland Middle School will implement a multi-faceted approach that includes embedding self-efficacy lessons focused on mindset and skills into Panther Time throughout the year, ensuring that staff receive professional learning on self-efficacy theory and classroom strategies with at least 90% participation. Teachers will be expected to incorporate self-efficacy practices into their daily instruction, with classroom observations confirming the use of these strategies in at least 80% of classrooms, while students will complete monthly surveys to monitor their self-efficacy perceptions and inform instructional adjustments. Additionally, students meeting with counselors, deans, or administrators during Student Success Meetings will participate in individual self-efficacy check-ins using a standardized protocol, creating multiple touchpoints throughout the year to reinforce and measure growth in student self-efficacy.
goals.engagement_strategies: 1) The school will communicate this SIP goal to all families via email and by posting this SIP on the school website. 2) During Principal Cassaro’s Ask Me Anything (AMA) quarterly meetings with families, this goal and progress toward this goal will be reviewed. 3) Monthly family emails will be sent to families about the self- efficacy topics covered in Panther Time, including strategies that can be used at home to increase self-efficacy. 4) Survey results will be shared with families quarterly. 5) Students who demonstrate self-efficacy with be highlighted in the Panther Pride Spotlight in the school.

goals.strategies_summarized: Northstar Middle School will implement a comprehensive, multi-tiered approach to improve student ELA skills by providing targeted before-school support during second semester, in-class small group instruction delivered by teachers and instructional assistants, and additional support during Advisory periods—all with progress monitored through participation tracking, FastBridge MOY and EOY assessments, and MTSS team data analysis.
