goals.strategies_summarized: Northstar Middle School will implement a comprehensive multi-tiered approach to improve student math skills, including targeted before-school math support and in-class small group instruction provided by teachers and instructional aides, with progress monitored through FastBridge assessments and MTSS data tracking. These coordinated efforts, measured through participation rates, attendance records, and spring 2026 FastBridge assessment data, are designed to move students from high or low risk categories toward low or minimal risk performance levels.

goals.strategies_summarized: Northstar Middle School will implement a comprehensive approach to foster belonging by first engaging all students in discussions about the meaning and key indicators of belonging through their Support Group (6th period). To complement this foundational work, the school will offer all students at least one choice-driven learning project in Support Group that allows them to explore content and skills aligned with their interests. Additionally, all teachers across core content areas will provide students with opportunities to demonstrate their competency through varied and individualized assessment methods, ensuring that students have agency in how they show their learning and can see themselves reflected in the school's academic expectations.

goals.outcome: Decrease the number of Ns in ELA from Quarter 1 and 3 to Semester 1 and 2 through effective use of Tier 2 interventions like Safety Net and WIN.
goals.currentdata: Last year, we collected data on the effectiveness of our Grade 7 Safety Net, minimizing the number of Ns (1 N S1, 3 Ns S2). We want to collect data in Grade 6 and 8 this year, and minimize the number of Ns in those classes as well.

strategies.action: Data Collection
strategies.measures: Compare number of N grades from Q 1 and 3 to Semester 1 and 2.

strategies.action: Systemic Interventions
strategies.measures: Effectively use Tier 2 interventions like WIN and Safety Net for ELA. Collect data on the use of WIN for students with Ns.

strategies.action: Professional Learning
strategies.measures: Ongoing professional learning on teacher responsiveness when students do not learn or feel excluded from class content.

goals.strategies_summarized: Redmond Middle School will implement a comprehensive approach to decrease the number of N grades in ELA by establishing systemic Tier 2 interventions, including WIN and Safety Net programs, while collecting data on their effectiveness and tracking N grade trends from Quarter 1 and 3 compared to Semester 1 and 2. Teachers will engage in ongoing professional learning focused on responsiveness to students who are not learning or feel excluded from class content, enabling them to better support struggling learners. Through this combination of targeted interventions, data monitoring, and professional development, the school aims to create a more inclusive and supportive ELA environment that reduces the incidence of N grades.
goals.engagement_strategies: • Continuous monitoring of the biweekly D and N report and systematic approaches to ensure students receive support. • Partnership between Administration, Counseling and Case Managers (IEP, 504, ML, CIS) • Parent contact and the use of Canvas to support students at home.

goals.currentdata: In Semester 1 of 2024, 23 RMS students did not pass Algebra at Redmond High School. All these students earned Level 1 on the SBA in Grade 8. We now require all students in Grade 8 to take Algebra.

strategies.action: Data Collection
strategies.measures: Compare number of N grades from Q 1 and 3 to Semester 1 and 2.

strategies.action: Teacher Collaboration
strategies.measures: Collaborate with Algebra teachers to ensure a guaranteed and viable curriculum in Algebra, especially since some Algebra teachers have Safety Net support while others are implementing a pilot curriculum. Collect data on percent of Ns in different classes.

strategies.action: Systemic Interventions

strategies.action: Professional Learning
strategies.measures: Ongoing professional learning on teacher responsiveness when students do not learn or feel excluded from class content.

goals.strategies_summarized: Redmond Middle School will decrease the number of N grades in Algebra by implementing a comprehensive approach that includes comparing N grade data across quarters and semesters, collaborating with Algebra teachers to ensure consistent curriculum implementation and collect class-specific data on N grades, and systematically deploying Tier 2 interventions such as WIN and Safety Net while monitoring their effectiveness. Additionally, the school will provide ongoing professional learning to help teachers respond more effectively when students struggle or feel disconnected from course content, creating a more supportive learning environment that ultimately reduces the incidence of failing grades.

goals.outcome: Increase “Sense of Belonging” percentages on Panorama from Spring 2024 to Spring 2025, with specific attention to the following question: “How much support do the adults at your school give you?”
goals.currentdata: In the Spring of 2025, 56 percent of students shared that the adults at Redmond Middle School provide either “a huge amount of support” (13 percent) or “a lot of support” (43 percent). Thirteen percent shared that they receive “a little bit” (10 percent) or “no support at all” (3 percent).

strategies.action: Student Focus Group
strategies.measures: Collect qualitative data on the support students receive from the adults at RMS and ideas on how we could provide more support.

strategies.action: WIN time data
strategies.measures: WIN is a flexible time of the day where students can receive academic support from their teachers. We will collect qualitative and quantitative data on the effectiveness of this Tier 2 intervention.

strategies.action: Professional Learning
strategies.measures: Ongoing professional learning on teacher responsiveness when students do not learn or feel excluded from class content.

goals.strategies_summarized: Redmond Middle School will implement a multi-faceted approach to increase students' sense of belonging and perceived support from adults. The school will conduct student focus groups to gather qualitative data on current support levels and identify improvement opportunities, while simultaneously collecting data on the effectiveness of WIN time—a flexible intervention period where teachers provide academic support to students. Additionally, the school will engage in ongoing professional learning focused on teacher responsiveness and ensuring that all students feel included in classroom content, fostering a more supportive school environment overall.
goals.engagement_strategies: • Parent survey on what they want from their students’ middle school experience • Share student focus group data with teachers

name: Renaissance School of Arts and Reasoning

goals.outcome: As measured by the Smarter Balanced Assessment (SBA), the proficiency of 8th grade students will improve from ‘weak’ in the 2024-25 school year to ‘strong’ in the 2025-26 school year for Target 8, Informational Text: “Given an inference or conclusion, use explicit details and implicit information from the text to support the inference or conclusion provided.”
goals.currentdata: There are three targets on the 2024-25 SBA in which 8th grade students at RSAR achieved ‘weak’ proficiency, including Target 8. A weakly proficient score on this target indicates that students struggle to use details from a text to support an inference. Building this skill will help students understand what they read in all subjects, not just ELA. Moving from ‘weak’ to ‘strong’ proficiency will better prepare students for the tougher reading and thinking tasks they will face in high school.

strategies.action: During novel studies in ELA, students will explain what details in the text help them infer about characters, themes, or events.
strategies.measures: ELA teachers will share brief samples of student responses or discussion notes to show that evidence-and-inference practice is happening consistently.

strategies.action: Teachers will incorporate close-reading routines, such as annotating key details or identifying evidence, when working with informational texts.
strategies.measures: Teachers will periodically review and discuss student work to confirm that close- reading routines are effective across subject areas.

strategies.action: Teachers will regularly model their thinking by “talking through” how they make an inference and choose supporting details, then guide students in practicing the same process.
strategies.measures: Teachers will review notes and student work to ensure think-alouds and guided practice are being used consistently.

goals.strategies_summarized: Renaissance School of Arts and Reasoning will implement a multi-faceted approach to strengthen students' ability to support inferences with textual evidence. Teachers will model their inferential thinking through think-alouds, demonstrating how to select supporting details before guiding students through the same process, with consistency monitored through review of student work and notes. Additionally, close-reading routines such as annotation and evidence identification will be incorporated across subjects, with periodic review of student work to assess effectiveness, while ELA teachers will have students explain how textual details support inferences about characters, themes, and events during novel studies, with progress tracked through shared samples of student responses and discussion notes.

goals.focus_area: Math Fluency to support Algebra Readiness
goals.outcome: To better prepare students for Algebra 1 as 7th or 8th graders, the percentage of 6th grade students earning scores of proficient or better on the Smarter Balanced Assessment (SBA) will improve from 61% in the 2024-25 school year to 75% in the 2025-26 school year.
goals.currentdata: Smarter Balanced Assessment (SBA) scores show 61% of 6th grade students showing scores of proficient or better in the 2024- 25 school year. FastBridge assessments reveal gaps in foundational math skills (e.g., multiplication, fractions). Struggles with basic fluency impact students’ ability to engage with more complex math concepts. Math anxiety is prevalent, and lack of fluency contributes to low confidence.

strategies.action: Students will engage in weekly math fluency activities focused on core prerequisite skills.
strategies.measures: Teachers will maintain a weekly log of fluency activities; lesson plans will reflect integration.

strategies.action: Students identified for additional support will participate in small-group math interventions during intervention periods.
strategies.measures: Intervention groups will be documented with attendance records and progress monitoring tools.

strategies.action: Students will reflect monthly on their math fluency progress using math journals or digital goal- setting tools.
strategies.measures: Teachers will review journals quarterly; student reflections will be part of student-led conferences.

goals.strategies_summarized: Renaissance School of Arts and Reasoning will implement a comprehensive approach to boost 6th grade math proficiency on the SBA from 61% to 75% by integrating weekly math fluency activities focused on core prerequisite skills into regular instruction, while documenting these activities through teacher logs and lesson plan integration. Students identified as needing additional support will participate in targeted small-group math interventions during designated intervention periods, with progress monitored through attendance records and progress monitoring tools. Additionally, students will engage in monthly self-reflection on their math fluency progress using math journals or digital goal-setting tools, with teacher reviews occurring quarterly and student reflections incorporated into student-led conferences to ensure ongoing accountability and growth.
goals.engagement_strategies: The School Improvement Plan is shaped by ongoing feedback from families and teachers, who consistently identify writing fluency, math fluency, and emotional regulation as top areas of need for students in middle school. These insights directly inform the school’s goals and ensure that the plan reflects what matters most to our community. Math teachers will utilize three programs to engage families on math work, including XtraMath, ALEKS, and Big Ideas Math. All three platforms can be used to monitor student understanding and progress over time. Additionally, XtraMath generates reports and certificates which can be sent automatically to parents and teachers depending on user preferences. During student-led conferences, which are bi-annual, students will self-select math work that they are proud of to show to their families. They will discuss why they are proud of the work, the circumstances that helped them be successful, and how they could have improved upon the work if applicable.

goals.outcome: By the end of the school year, at least 85% of students will be able to identify at least four core emotions and demonstrate at least two self-regulation strategies, as measured by teacher checklists, SEL reflections, and student self-assessments.
goals.currentdata: Increase in behavioral referrals related to emotional outbursts and peer conflict. Student and teacher surveys indicate a need for more emotional regulation tools. Research supports that SEL improves academic success and school climate.

strategies.action: Students will participate in weekly SEL lessons focused on emotional awareness and regulation strategies.
strategies.measures: Teachers will follow a scope and sequence for SEL instruction.

strategies.action: The SPED classroom will include a calm space or self-regulation area where students can take breaks when needed.
strategies.measures: Usage will be tracked (informally or with reflection tools).

strategies.action: Students will engage in regular emotional check-ins during advisory periods using visual tools like emotion thermometers or mood meters.
strategies.measures: Teachers will incorporate daily check- ins consistently.

goals.strategies_summarized: Renaissance School of Arts and Reasoning will implement a comprehensive approach to help students identify core emotions and develop self-regulation strategies through weekly SEL lessons that follow a structured scope and sequence, combined with daily emotional check-ins during advisory periods using visual tools like emotion thermometers and mood meters. Additionally, the school will establish a calm space or self-regulation area in the SPED classroom where students can access breaks as needed, with usage tracked through informal monitoring and reflection tools. Progress toward the 85% achievement goal will be measured through teacher checklists, SEL reflections, and student self-assessments, with consistency in daily check-ins and adherence to the SEL instructional framework serving as key indicators of implementation fidelity.
goals.engagement_strategies: The School Improvement Plan is shaped by ongoing feedback from families and teachers, who consistently identify writing fluency, math fluency, and emotional regulation as top areas of need for students in middle school. These insights directly inform the school’s goals and ensure that the plan reflects what matters most to our community.

goals.focus_area: 6th grade ELA students Target 1-7 • Target 1: Citing textual evidence to support analysis and inferences • Target 2: Determining central ideas or themes and summarizing text • Target 3: Analyzing how individuals, events, and ideas develop • Target 4: Interpreting word meaning and tone • Target 5: Analyzing text structure and author’s craft • Target 6: Comparing texts and genres • Target 7: Integrating knowledge and ideas
goals.outcome: All 6th grade students will show growth in multiple target areas under Literacy Texts.
goals.currentdata: 6th-grade ELA teachers will focus on developing students’ reading comprehension skills, with a specific emphasis on literary texts utilizing both fiction and non-fiction genres. This instructional priority stems from SBA data (2024–2025), which revealed that it was a weaker section compared to others. The data further indicated that constructed-response and evidence- based reasoning questions related to literary passages were among the lowest-performing targets, particularly those assessing inference, theme development, and analysis of character and plot. Strengthening students’ ability to analyze and interpret literary texts is critical to ensuring overall reading proficiency and readiness for more complex literary analysis in upper grades. In addition, literary text comprehension supports broader literacy

goals.strategies_summarized: Rose Hill Middle School will support 6th grade literacy growth through a multi-faceted approach that includes frequent progress monitoring via FastBridge Universal Screener assessments administered three times throughout the year to identify students needing intervention and track effectiveness, combined with individualized goal-setting where students work with IEP and ML case managers to establish and reflect on literacy focus goals quarterly. The school will provide targeted academic interventions during Pride Time sessions, which occur twice weekly for 30 minutes, offering students specialized support tailored to their needs, while teachers collaborate in data-focused meetings to develop intentional strategies around identified literacy targets and ensure appropriate modifications and accommodations are implemented for students with IEPs, 504s, and those receiving Multi-Lingual services. Additionally, school leaders will conduct student listening sessions to understand student experiences and gather insights about effective learning strategies, information that will be shared and discussed among administrators and push-in teacher teams to refine instructional approaches and identify best practices for supporting literacy growth.
goals.engagement_strategies: As part of the student growth goal, teachers will collaborate with families to get feedback about content and skill. Based on family feedback, some instructions and assessments will be modified as per the students’ needs.

goals.focus_area: 6th Grade – Target B: Apply and extend previous understandings of multiplication and division to divide fractions by fractions. Target I: Develop understanding of statistical variability. 7th Grade – Target F: Solve real-life and mathematical problems involving angle measure, area, surface area, and volume Target G: Use random sampling to draw inferences about a population. Target I: Investigate chance processes and develop, use, and evaluate probability models
goals.outcome: By intentionally focusing on concepts identified on the math SBA as opportunities for improvement in 6th and 7th grade math, students will have a stronger foundation heading into Algebra, which will lead to more success in Algebra whether students take it in 7th or in 8th grade.
goals.currentdata: SBA: Last year, 80% of 6th graders (an increase of 8% from the previous year) and 78% of 7th graders (an increase of 10% from the previous year) scored a Level 3 (Met Standard) or Level 4 (Exceeded Standard) on the Math SBA. This is worthy of celebration and evidence that last year’s focus on providing students opportunities to retake assessments after reteaching/re- learning has taken place between attempts, so that they will continue learning after assessments, learn from their mistakes, and move closer to mastery, had a positive impact on student achievement. Last year on the SBA, 6th graders were Above the Proficiency Standard on all Concept and Procedures “Targets”. However, in the previous year, Target B was identified as a weakness, and Target I was the only one that was “At/Near Proficiency Standard”, so it is worthy of focusing on these specific areas. Last year on the SBA, 7th graders had two targets, Target F and Target G where they were “At/Near Proficiency Standard”, and another that Above Standard but still identified as an “Area of Weakness”: Target I.

goals.strategies_summarized: Rose Hill Middle School will strengthen students' mathematical foundations through collaborative, data-driven efforts among math teachers, including department Professional Learning Community meetings focused on identified concept and procedure targets, combined with targeted interventions such as FastBridge Universal Screener assessments administered three times yearly to monitor progress and identify students needing support, ALEKS practice activities to address skill gaps both within and beyond current curriculum, and Pride Time intervention sessions occurring twice weekly. Additionally, the school will gather student input through listening sessions to understand their experiences and self-efficacy with math strategies, while teachers utilize grade-level team meetings and ongoing ALEKS monitoring to ensure students are progressing toward stronger algebra readiness.
goals.engagement_strategies: Student Staffings: For students who continue to struggle despite the implementation of interventions, the school’s counselors schedule staffing meetings will all teachers, the student, and the student’s family. The goal is to create a partnership between the school, the student, and the family to support the student academically, socially, and emotionally. Specific actions are discussed and implemented as a result of these meetings.

goals.focus_group: School-Wide Houses and Continued Implementation of Restorative Practices
goals.outcome: To build community, encourage teamwork, reinforce the school values of Safe, Kind, and Responsible and promote school spirit, our school will implement a House system. Students and staff will be assigned to one of six houses, each representing core values and school pride. Continued implementation of restorative practices across the continuum (affective statements, affective questions, small impromptu conversations, circles, formal conferences), especially the 80% that are proactive, community-building focused, will lead to a greater sense of belonging for students.
goals.currentdata: A sense of belonging impacts student performance, attendance, peer relationships, and school culture. Each student will be assigned to a House (six different houses named for different sub-species of lions, our school mascot), with an even distribution of 6th, 7th, and 8th grade students per house. Students will be engaged in developing a house chant, motto, crest, and decorating their pod as they work collaboratively to create their house’s individual identity. Student leaders, “House Captains,” will be chosen to help lead the work. Houses will compete and earn points through house competitions (academic, behavior, and extracurricular activities), events, and meetings. Restorative Practices foster a greater sense of belonging by creating a supportive and inclusive environment where students feel valued and heard. These practices, such as restorative circles, encourage open dialogue and mutual respect among students and teachers, helping build strong relationships and a positive school climate. This approach promotes a sense of safety and belonging, which is critical for students’ emotional and academic development. In the Panorama Spring survey, 53% of students gave positive responses to questions related to a sense of belonging (15% of students gave negative responses and 32% gave neutral responses). This showed an increase in positive response rate in this category of 9% and a decrease in negative responses by 4% compared to the year before. While this is evidence that the

strategies.action: All students will be assigned randomly with all three grade levels included in each House. A special First House Meeting will introduce students to their houses within the first two weeks of school using FlexiSCHED. Students will stay in the same Houses for all three years.
strategies.measures: Each house will develop their identity by creating a house crest, motto, chant, and decorating their pod. All house events will take place during Advisory and/or during all- school assemblies or lunches.

strategies.action: Houses will earn points through academics, behavior, and extra-curricular activities. Examples: School fundraiser, spirit days, trivia, pod decoration, announcement competitions, hygiene drive, etc.
strategies.measures: There will be an increase in participation in spirit days, assembly contests, and other all school events due to a focus on house competitions. Houses will accumulate points throughout the year, with the highest-scoring house winning the House Cup.

strategies.action: The ten staff members who participated in an International Institute of Restorative Practices (IIRP) “Train-the-Trainers” three- day training in June, 2024 continue to plan and lead on- going professional development over the course of the school year during LEAP time.
strategies.measures: RHMS staff restorative practices trainers collaborate to develop and lead lessons to build off of last year’s all-staff trainings in the “Fundamentals of Restorative Practices” curriculum.

strategies.action: of the school year during LEAP time.
Continued implementation of practices across the Restorative Practices continuum.
strategies.measures: Proactiv restorative practices like Community Circles are embedded into Advisory curriculum over the course of the year. Teachers utilize fair process when establishing classroom norms and expectations. Administrators, counselors, Dean of Students, and teachers engage students in restorative circle to repair harm and restore relationships when conflict arises between students. Processing form modified to make the reflective questions more restorative, helping students focus on the impact their actions had on others.

goals.strategies_summarized: Rose Hill Middle School will establish a House system by randomly assigning all students, with mixed grade levels in each house, and introducing them to their assigned houses within the first two weeks of school through special First House Meetings where each house develops its identity through creating crests, mottos, chants, and pod decorations. Houses will earn points throughout the year via academics, behavior, and extracurricular participation in activities like spirit days, fundraisers, and competitions, with the highest-scoring house winning the House Cup to motivate increased engagement in school events. Additionally, ten staff members trained in International Institute of Restorative Practices will lead ongoing professional development during LEAP time, embedding proactive restorative practices such as community circles into the Advisory curriculum, utilizing fair process for classroom norms, and engaging students in restorative circles to repair harm and restore relationships when conflicts arise, ultimately creating a greater sense of belonging and community.
goals.engagement_strategies: The house structure, purpose of houses, and different house activities will be communicated to parents and families in the weekly newsletter that goes home to all RHMS families via ParentSquare. Parents will be reminded to encourage their students to wear their house colors on days there will be house meetings.

goals.outcome: All students will have an improved level of reading comprehension as measured by the annual SBA. All students will improve their knowledge of figurative language and usage of figurative language in their writing as measured by baseline assessments in the Fall of 2025 and summative assessments in Spring of 2026.
goals.currentdata: SBA results from Spring 2025 of current Stella Schola 6th, 7th, and 8th graders. This year’s 8th graders had 97% meet or exceed standard (52% Level 4, 45% Level 3) on the Spring ELA SBA last year as 7th graders. This year’s 7th graders had 90% meet or exceed standard (57% Level 4, 33% Level 3) on the Spring ELA SBA last year as 6th graders. This year’s 6th graders had 89% meet or exceed standard (81% Level 4, 8% Level 3) when they took the SBA at their elementary schools in 5th grade.

strategies.measures: Formative and summative classroom assessments will show student improvement in the identified areas.

strategies.action: Comprehension Q's and Fig. Lang. are both modeled through whole group instruction embedded into novel studies and explicit instruction, small group and independent work as well.

goals.strategies_summarized: Stella Schola Middle School will implement frequent mini-lessons using mentor texts to help students identify and analyze figurative language, supported by formative and summative classroom assessments to track improvement. Students will engage in creative writing assignments that require them to incorporate and revise their work to include specific types of figurative language, with progress measured through classroom assessments and end-of-unit projects. Additionally, comprehension strategies and figurative language instruction will be embedded throughout novel studies using a combination of whole group, small group, and independent work, with student learning demonstrated through end-of-novel unit assessments and projects.
goals.engagement_strategies: Communication of student progress via parent-teacher conferences twice yearly; regularly scheduled ParentSquare classroom updates; emails to parents to communicate progress.

goals.outcome: All students will meet the Priority goal of success in Algebra (as measured by a C or better grade in Algebra) by end of 8th grade.
goals.currentdata: SBA results from Spring 2025. Students can demonstrate Algebra-readiness by successful grades in Math 6+ and Math 7+ and SBA scores of 3 or 4 on the 6th and 7th grade SBA (demonstrating at-grade-level performance). On last year’s Math SBA, 79% of 6th graders were at or above standard (48% Level 4, 31% Level 3), 87% of 7th graders were at or above standard (77% Level 4, 10% Level 3), and 97% of 8th graders were at or above standard (66% Level 4, 31% Level 3).

goals.strategies_summarized: Stella Schola Middle School will implement a comprehensive math support program focused on building foundational skills and problem-solving abilities. Students will participate in monthly math fact quizzes and weekly Math Olympics competitions that progressively increase in difficulty, with progress monitored through both timed and untimed assessments. Additionally, the school will incorporate daily word problem practice during whole group and small group instruction, with mastery evaluated through end-of-unit assessments to ensure all students achieve a C or better grade in Algebra by the end of 8th grade.

goals.focus_group: All students in 9th grade who have an IEP.
goals.focus_area: 9th grade students with an IEP earning 6+ credits.
goals.outcome: All 9th grade students will earn 6+ credits, including students with an IEP.
goals.currentdata: - Our school and district changed from a 7-credit schedule to a 6-credit schedule; students no longer have a large buffer of ‘extra’ credits. A student who fails courses in 9th grade is at greater risk now of not graduating on time. - Eastlake has 44 freshmen who have an IEP (7% of freshmen). Of these 44 students, more than half of them (24 of the 44) have at least one D or N at the end of 1st quarter. These 24 students are in danger of not passing their classes and earning full credit.

strategies.action: Link Crew teams for all freshmen
strategies.measures: LC Leaders recruited and trained. Incoming freshmen orientation before 1st day of school. Ongoing LC activities during year

strategies.action: Homeroom activities for freshmen
strategies.measures: Freshman HR Coordinator Freshman-only activities planned

strategies.action: Counselors and administrators identify, monitor, and connect with freshmen in their alpha who are on the D/N list.
strategies.measures: Spreadsheets maintained that show freshmen from the D/N list, whether there is a case manager, information known, and what has been tried and what is next.

strategies.action: Almost all freshmen with IEPs are in co-taught English
strategies.measures: Teachers complete Cornerstone PD for co-

strategies.action: and/or math. We will ensure all co-taught teachers receive training for co-taught instructional strategies.
strategies.measures: teachers. Teachers attend Eastlake PD on ‘how to co- teach’ instructional strategies, and discuss what works and what does not.

strategies.action: After 1st semester encourage teachers to timesheet additional work with students to improve any N grade to passing grade.
strategies.measures: Teachers submit grade change request forms.

strategies.action: Counselors will develop graduation plan for any freshman with 1st semester N grade, such as Credit Recovery class for 2nd semester or Summer School.
strategies.measures: Freshmen with 1st semester N grades have individual graduation plan.

goals.strategies_summarized: Eastlake High School will support all 9th grade students, including those with IEPs, in earning 6+ credits through a comprehensive multi-pronged approach. The school will establish Link Crew teams and homeroom activities to provide freshman support and community, ensure that students with IEPs are placed in co-taught English and/or math classes with teachers trained in co-teaching instructional strategies, and have counselors and administrators actively monitor and connect with students on the D/N list using maintained spreadsheets. Additionally, after the first semester, teachers will be encouraged to complete additional work with students earning N grades while counselors develop individualized graduation plans—such as credit recovery or summer school—for any freshman with first semester N grades.
goals.engagement_strategies: Incoming Freshman Parent Night in Spring. Incoming Freshman invited in during Wolf Strong Week in Spring. Registration support in Spring for incoming freshmen. New flexibility to change from Honors to On-level English or social studies with no penalty. Freshman Parent Night during LEAP week. Message to families at the end of 1st quarter: explain how and why to check grades in Skyward. Administrators will attend professional development by Dr. Karen Mapp to learn additional family engagement strategies, and we plan to apply to be a focus school to continue this work throughout the year.

goals.focus_area: ML students have been graduating at a lower rate than our overall school’s graduation rate.
goals.outcome: ML students will graduate at the same rate as our school’s overall graduation rate, with the goal of 100% of all students graduating.
goals.currentdata: For the graduating class of 2024, 66.7% of ML students graduated on time, compared to our overall graduation rate of 97.68%. The graduating class of 2025 had only ten ML seniors: Five (50%) graduated on time, one (10%) did not, and four (40%) have IEPs and are continuing their high school education at our district’s Transition Academy.

strategies.action: Biweekly D/N list sent to all counselors, case managers, ML teachers, and administrators.

strategies.measures: Spreadsheets maintained that show ML students from the D/N list, IEP/504 status, information known, what has been tried and what is next. Communication logs.

strategies.measures: Notes from student discussions. Discuss notes at admin/counselor pulse meeting for possible next steps.

strategies.measures: Tips and strategies are included in the newsletter.

strategies.measures: Classrooms of the Week articles

strategies.action: Message sent to all teachers at end of 1st and 3rd quarter, emphasizing the challenges of ML students passing at the end of the semester if they are failing at the mid-point.
strategies.measures: Messages sent to all teachers that describe this challenge and emphasize its importance.

strategies.action: After 1st semester encourage teachers to timesheet additional work with students to improve any N grade to passing. Also consider schedule changes into Credit Recovery class for 2nd semester.
strategies.measures: Teachers submit grade change request forms. Counselors process schedule changes.

goals.strategies_summarized: Eastlake High School will implement a comprehensive monitoring and support system for multilingual (ML) students at risk of not graduating. The school will send biweekly D/N lists to counselors, case managers, ML teachers, and administrators, who will then identify, monitor, and maintain detailed spreadsheets tracking ML students' progress, IEP/504 status, and intervention attempts. Additionally, the school will gather direct feedback from ML students through street data conversations to understand their challenges and support needs, communicate regularly with all teachers about the critical importance of ML student success through mid-point and end-of-quarter messages, and highlight effective instructional strategies for supporting ML students in staff newsletters and Classrooms of the Week features. Finally, after each semester, teachers will be encouraged to provide additional support to help students improve failing grades, and counselors will facilitate schedule changes into Credit Recovery classes when needed to ensure ML students graduate at the same rate as the overall school population.
goals.engagement_strategies: Street data from parents at our International Parent Night. Invitations sent to all parents of ML and exited ML students. What do they think about our school’s support for their students? What do they appreciate? What can our school do better? What should we know?

goals.focus_area: Tardies (T and L) and unexcused absences (U and W)
goals.outcome: The number of tardies (T and L) and unexcused absences (U and W) will decrease this year when compared to last year: - The total number of T/L for our school will decrease. - The number of students with 20+ T/L will decrease. - The total number of U/W for our school will decrease. - The number of students with 20+ U/W will decrease.
goals.currentdata: Last year our students were Tardy or Late 11,892 times for their academic classes (does not include Wolf Time). This is an undercount; some teachers started recording their attendance several minutes into the class period because so many students were chronically late. Last year 130 students were marked T/L 20+ times. Last year 2194 students had at least one unexcused absence (U or W), and 711 students had at least 20.

strategies.action: Explain to students and families the importance of regular punctual attendance.
strategies.measures: Messages included in newsletters.

strategies.action: Assigned academic intervention teachers to develop and implement interventions for tardies and for unexcused absences.
strategies.measures: 0.6 FTE for unexcused absences intervention. 0.4 FTE for tardies intervention.

strategies.action: Interventions developed for different thresholds of T/L and U/W, with increasing consequences for increasing levels. (see below)
strategies.measures: Spreadsheets maintained to show students at different levels of intervention.

goals.strategies_summarized: Eastlake High School will implement a comprehensive approach to reduce tardies and unexcused absences by combining family engagement, targeted interventions, and progressive consequences. The school will communicate the importance of regular punctual attendance to students and families through newsletter messages, while assigning dedicated academic intervention teachers (0.6 FTE for unexcused absences and 0.4 FTE for tardies) to develop and implement customized interventions based on different thresholds of violations. Interventions will feature escalating consequences for increasing levels of tardies and unexcused absences, with spreadsheets maintained to track student progress and ensure consistent monitoring across the school.
goals.engagement_strategies: Interventions for both tardies and for unexcused absences: - Level 1: Email sent to students and parents, informing them of the problem and why this is important. - Level 2: Meet with student, start learning about student, assign detention, inform parents.

The school will establish an intervention class for 9th graders and offer a Learning Center model for credit retrieval, both tracked through Skyward data, while also enabling independent course work completion as an alternative pathway. Additionally, the MTSS team will conduct monthly meetings to review referral data, and grade-level teams will hold bi-weekly meetings to discuss student progress both academically and social-emotionally, ensuring coordinated support across all dimensions of student success.

The school will establish oversight mechanisms through MTSS team monthly meetings to monitor student referrals and progress, supplemented by bi-weekly team meetings to assess both academic and social-emotional development, with progress documented through meeting notes and referral data. These interconnected strategies are designed to ensure that all credit-deficient 10th grade students complete their required credits and graduate on-time by Spring 2028.

goals.strategies_summarized: Emerson High School will implement weekly interest-based homeroom classes designed to strengthen connections between students and staff through shared interests, while also establishing weekly intervention classes organized by grade level to provide targeted academic and social-emotional support. To ensure the effectiveness of these initiatives, the school will conduct monthly MTSS team meetings to review referral data and monitor systemic progress, complemented by bi-weekly team meetings focused on discussing individual student progress both academically and socially-emotionally. Through a combination of session surveys, interest surveys, teacher formative data, and detailed meeting notes, Emerson will collect ongoing evidence to track progress toward increasing favorable responses in the Sense of Belonging category from 69% to 75% by Spring 2026.

goals.currentdata: Currently, 80% of Hispanic and 65% of ML students graduate as compared to 92% of students overall. Current SBA scores from previous school years show a persistent achievement gap. Most recent SY24-25 data shows: • Math overall (53%); Hispanic (30%); ML (34%) • ELA overall (82%); Hispanic (62%); ML (61%) • Science overall (84%); Hispanic (72%); ML (71%) 25.26 Quarter one grades also show that although ML students comprise 11% of our population, they earned 1/3 of the Ds and Ns.

goals.strategies_summarized: Juanita High School will close the graduation gap between underrepresented subgroups and their peers through multiple coordinated interventions, including the continuation of credit recovery programs (FLEX Academy and summer sessions) to help students earn credits toward graduation, implementation of safety net classes for 9th and 10th grade core courses to improve quarterly and semester grades, and team-taught multilingual classes designed to support multilingual and Hispanic students. Additionally, the school will conduct student listening sessions to gather qualitative feedback from students about barriers to graduation, allowing administrators to identify and address specific student needs. Progress will be monitored through monthly tracking of students completing credits, quarterly and semester grade assessments, and analysis of meeting minutes from listening sessions to ensure these strategies effectively reduce the graduation gap.

goals.strategies_summarized: Lake Washington High School will support freshmen in earning at least six credits through a multi-faceted approach that includes building strong relationships, providing early intervention, and implementing instructional support. The school will engage students through the AVID program, conduct individual counselor meetings during the first quarter and end of October, and facilitate parent involvement through orientations and curriculum nights that introduce families to academic supports and programs. Additionally, the school will monitor student progress by running an N-list at the end of each quarter, conducting attendance check-ins through an attendance specialist, and implementing Tier I instructional strategies that provide multiple opportunities for students to demonstrate proficiency and earn credits.
goals.engagement_strategies: National Honor Society Students are going to build short videos that will help 9th graders develop skills for success in collaboration with ILT. ILT will offer brief coaching to teachers around positive behavior interventions for 9th grade students, as well as coaching for PLCs. This support will be offered to teachers via the Behavior Support Form. Ninth Grade Parent Orientation was provided for parents of all 9th grade students in August. A transcript of the presentation was provided for those who could not attend in person. Parents met the administrative team and heard from leadership students about how students can get engaged. Small group choice sessions were offered on AP coursework, AVID and ML support, attendance and behavior support, technology access, clubs and sports. Families of students pre-identified as needing support for academics and attendance were invited to a Connections lunch before school started and also received a direct invitation to Curriculum Night. School supplies were provided for students and distributed by the Family Engagement specialist.

goals.strategies_summarized: Lake Washington High School will implement a comprehensive multi-faceted approach to support on-time graduation, beginning with proactive communication through regular email and Parent Square messages to students and families, while counselors provide targeted support by pushing into the RISE program on a bi-weekly rotation basis to assist students directly in the classroom. Additionally, the school will identify at-risk juniors and seniors who have not met Washington State graduation requirements, assign adult monitors to track their progress through Canvas courses, and send "at-risk letters" every nine weeks to maintain accountability and engagement. The school will also leverage PLC-trained teachers to improve instructional practices, expand peer mentoring programs, and host summer school sign-up sessions and HOP sessions to ensure students have the resources and support necessary to meet graduation requirements by the end of the school year.
goals.engagement_strategies: LWHS will host focus groups. ILT also plans to conduct student and teacher focus groups around classroom strategies of engagement and connection. Tier III Team focuses on three different areas: Attendance, academics and SEL. Each of these teams uses data to identify interventions and celebrate success. Parents will be integral to the success of this work, as we engage them in understanding the supports that are in place so that they can take advantage of them.

goals.outcome: Fall 2024: Student Sense of Belonging was at 46 percent Spring 2025: Student Sense of Belonging was at 50 percent Goal for Spring of 2026: Student Sense of Belonging will be at 70 percent (Students will test in fall of 2025 as well as in spring of 2026)

goals.strategies_summarized: To increase student sense of belonging from 50 percent in Spring 2025 to 70 percent by Spring 2026, Lake Washington High School will launch a "Connect Before Content" initiative that encourages staff to begin classes with relationship-building activities, while the Instructional Leadership Team provides ongoing professional development through PLC-focused work. The school will also expand student leadership and peer mentoring programs to foster cross-grade relationships, create opportunities for student input through leadership team representation and check-ins like "Donuts with Dr. Bell," and establish a quarterly review cycle where the Building Leadership Team analyzes SEL and climate data to adjust supports as needed. These coordinated efforts, supported by PLC-trained teachers and leaders who will offer training during staff development time, aim to create a more connected and inclusive school community that significantly improves students' sense of belonging.

goals.strategies_summarized: Redmond High School will implement a comprehensive support system targeting 9th grade students through dedicated homerooms that foster peer and adult connections, the Best Year program, and co-taught courses in English, Math, BITES, and Lifetime Wellness that provide specialized instruction and lower student-teacher ratios. The school will also establish Link Crew orientation and ongoing connections throughout the year, while systematically monitoring attendance and grade data through quarterly progress reviews conducted by deans, teachers, counselors, and administrators. Additionally, the MTSS Academic team will utilize a Skyward "watchlist" to track student achievement and provide targeted support through bi-monthly meetings, ensuring that at-risk students receive the intervention necessary to earn credit in all enrolled classes.

goals.strategies_summarized: Redmond High School will implement a comprehensive multi-faceted approach to increase graduation rates to 100% by June 2026, including offering credit recovery options through Apex and summer school, expanding dual credit and personalized pathway opportunities like Running Start, and establishing an MTSS Academic team to monitor at-risk students using a Skyward watchlist. The school will strengthen instructional quality through PLC collaboration focused on culturally responsive teaching, supported by August training and dedicated collaboration time, while simultaneously removing barriers to graduation through restorative discipline practices, the on-site Communities in Schools program that directly connects families to resources, and multi-lingual family nights that build community engagement. Additionally, the school will improve tracking of transfer students and coordinate closely among counselors, administrators, and support staff to ensure all student groups receive personalized guidance and intervention tailored to their needs.
goals.engagement_strategies: • Dedicated staff meeting time for school/home communication. • Invite ML families to school meetings, and secure interpreters or native speakers for support. • Communicate with families about alternative pathways (WANIC, Running Start, etc) to ensure they are aware of options available for their student. • Present SIP and progress monitoring during PTSA Board meetings and General Membership meetings. • Connect with families during GT, IEP, and 504 meetings to continue building supportive relationships. • Curriculum Night – families visit RHS and travel their student’s schedule to meet teachers and learn about classes.

goals.strategies_summarized: Redmond High School will implement a comprehensive approach to increase students' sense of belonging through multiple interconnected initiatives: establishing homeroom as a dedicated time for connection through collaborative planning and YaHerd videos, welcoming 9th graders through the Link Crew program with dedicated staff coordinators, implementing a consistent classroom cell phone policy to foster interpersonal engagement, and recognizing students through the Mustang of the Month program. Additionally, the school will support student extracurricular clubs and affinity groups such as Latinos Unidos, AWARE, the Black Student Union, Fellowship of Christian Athletes, the Indian Student Association, and SAGA to create spaces where students can connect around shared identities and interests. Finally, student focus groups will provide qualitative feedback on the school experience, ensuring that student voices inform ongoing efforts to strengthen belonging across the campus.

Cell Phone Policy, Best Year program, etc) to create awareness and opportunity for feedback. • Equity team work to develop community mentor project for student engagement.

goals.focus_group: 9th grade students will earn all six credits during their 9th grade year.
goals.focus_area: Our focus group includes 9th grade students who either have not completed Algebra 1 or show academic evidence of need in the first quarter.
goals.outcome: Increase the percentage of 9th students earning all credits from baseline of 91.14% in 2024-25 to 93% in 2025-26.
goals.currentdata: Data from previous years for students who start at Tesla STEM, but who have not successfully completed Algebra 1, show evidence of ongoing academic struggle. Academic data from 1st quarter grades, specifically grades below 70% (D+, D and N grades) will be reviewed and used to track ongoing achievement.

strategies.action: Inform all teachers of which students have not yet completed Algebra 1 and make individual support plans for each student.
strategies.measures: Monthly academic checks for students in the focus area.

strategies.action: Administrators will analyze academic success data at each Skyward grade update period to identify any students who are falling below target.
strategies.measures: Ensure that every student who is falling below passing scores has been brought forward on a student of concern conference or receives a Tier 2 support.

goals.strategies_summarized: Nikola Tesla STEM High School will implement a two-pronged approach to increase 9th grade credit completion from 91.14% to 93%. First, the school will identify all students who have not yet completed Algebra 1 and develop individual support plans for each, with monthly academic check-ins to monitor progress in this focus area. Second, administrators will analyze academic data at each Skyward grade update period to identify struggling students and ensure that all students falling below passing scores receive either a student of concern conference or Tier 2 support services.
goals.engagement_strategies: Tier 1: Administrators will communicate with all 9th grade families of the importance of successfully earning all credits and the specific impacts of the move from a 7-period to a 6-period day. Tier 2: Counselors will engage in family meetings at the quarter if a student is not independently showing a trajectory of successfully earning all credits, including establishing an expected schedule to attend teacher office hours.

goals.focus_group: Students who are receiving special education or 504 support.
goals.focus_area: Increase 4-year graduation rates as appropriate for students receiving special education services or 504 support.
goals.outcome: Students who receive special education or 504 supports will graduate at the same rate as their peers.
goals.currentdata: The 2025 4-year graduation rate for all students was 97%. The number of students in the target group is suppressed for privacy. However, in 2025, there was a discrepancy between students with disabilities and students without on 4-year graduation rates.

strategies.action: Tier 1: Deliberate and persistent focus on earning all necessary graduation credits through all grades.
strategies.measures: Semester grade reports indicate student success on earning all credits.

strategies.action: Tier 3: Individualized plans to graduation for every senior who is in danger of not graduating, including adjusted schedules, access to mental health support, safety plans, and regular check-ins.
strategies.measures: Document regular meetings with students and families which include information about school and district resources for mental health support.

strategies.action: Engage with students and families through the IEP process to ensure the IEP fully supports the students’ needs.
strategies.measures: Ensure that every IEP is compliant and complete.

goals.strategies_summarized: Nikola Tesla STEM High School will implement a multi-tiered approach to support special education and 504 students in graduating at rates comparable to their peers. The school will maintain a deliberate focus on credit completion across all grades, monitored through semester grade reports, while ensuring every IEP is compliant and fully addresses student needs through active engagement with families in the IEP process. Additionally, the school will develop individualized graduation plans for at-risk seniors, including adjusted schedules, mental health support access, safety plans, and regular check-ins with documented meetings that connect students and families to necessary school and district resources.
goals.engagement_strategies: Include graduation and credit discussion in IEP and 504 annual meetings to ensure that students and families are aware of credit status. Co-create and document the recovery plan.

goals.focus_area: Students in grades 9 – 11 will synthesize from multiple texts to improve their synthesis writing.
goals.outcome: By the end of the 2025-26 school year, 11th grade students will earn a mean score of 4.3 or higher on the AP exam Synthesis Essay. This ELA skill supports STEM courses and is a requirement for achieving STEM literacy.
goals.currentdata: Student achievement on the AP Synthesis essay in 2025 was 4.24, representing a consistent participation of over 90% of 11th grade students participating in the AP Language and Composition exam.

strategies.action: Synthesis is taught several times in all ELA classes, building on skills from previous years.
strategies.measures: Teacher alignment with expectations and common scoring of the synthesis essays to ensure fidelity across teachers.

strategies.action: Teachers will deliver explicit teaching on synthesis using exemplar essays.
strategies.measures: Teacher pairs will intentionally and consistently deliver explicit teaching on synthesis; student achievement will show growth in their writing throughout the year.

strategies.action: Students will complete 5 practice essays in 11th grade.
strategies.measures: In addition to teacher feedback, students will self-assess their writing through the portfolio review.

goals.strategies_summarized: Nikola Tesla STEM High School will implement a multi-faceted approach to improve 11th grade students' AP exam Synthesis Essay performance by reinforcing synthesis skills across all ELA classes while ensuring teacher alignment and consistent scoring practices. Teachers will deliver explicit, intentional instruction on synthesis using exemplar essays through coordinated teacher pairs, with student growth monitored throughout the year, while students complete five practice essays and engage in self-assessment through portfolio reviews to internalize feedback and track their progress. These coordinated efforts in skill-building, explicit instruction, and student reflection will work together to help students achieve the target mean score of 4.3 or higher on the AP exam Synthesis Essay.
goals.engagement_strategies: Through the new learning management system, Canvas, families can see student progress and achievement, including teacher feedback on individual essays. Tier 2 strategy is to engage families directly when students are below the expected achievement, through teacher, counselor or administrator meetings.
